children.definition: flying, winged, Διὸς π. κύων, i.e. eagle, A. Pr. 1022, cf. Ag. 136 (lyr.); π. ὄφις Id. Eu. 181; ὄρνις, οἰωνός, S. Ph. 955, Ant. 1082; Ἔρως, ἵπποι, E. Hipp. 1275 (lyr.), IT 193 (lyr.); ἅρμα Pl. Phdr. 246e; also of arrows, π. ἰοί S. Ph. 166 (anap.); βέλη E. HF 179; π. φυγή, of birds, Pl. Prt. 320e.

τὰ π. winged creatures, birds, A. Ch. 591 (lyr.), S. Aj. 168 (anap.), E. Ion 504 (lyr.), etc.; πτηνὸν ὀρνίθων γένος Ar. Av. 1707; πτηνῶν γένη Id. Th. 46; opp. τὰ πεζά, Pl. Smp. 207a; opp. τὰ πεζά and τὰ πλωτά, Arist. HA 488a1, cf. 542a23: hence πταναὶ θῆραι the pursuit of winged game, S. Ph. 1146 (lyr.); ἡ [θήρα] τῶν π. Pl. Lg. 823b: of young birds, fledged, E. Tr. 146 (lyr.).
swift-footed, παρδάλεις, κάμηλοι, Lib. Ep. 219.5, 1402.3.

children.label: II
children.definition: πτηνοὶ μῦθοι, Homerʼs ἔπεα πτερόεντα, E. Or. 1176: but κοῦφοι καὶ π. λόγοι fleeting, idle words, Pl. Lg. 717d; π. ὄνειροι E. IT 571; πτηνὰς διώκεις ἐλπίδας fleeting hopes, Id. Fr. 271.
πτανὰ ἰσχύς soaring, aspiring strength, Pi. Fr. 107.3.
terror, Aq., Sm., Thd. Pr. 18.7.
able to fly, winged, λόγοι Jul. Ep. 191.
flight, A. Pr. 488, Arist. PA 639b2, EN 1174a31, Q.S. 12.5 (pl.): metaph. of rapid reading, ἡ περὶ τὴν ἀνάγνωσιν π. Lib. Ep. 949.2.

definition: πτήσσω (never πτήττω), Ar. V. 1490, X. Cyr. 3.3.18: fut. πτήξω AP 12.141 codd. ( Mel.): aor. ἔπτηξα E. HF 974, etc., Dor. ἔπταξα Pi. P. 4.57, Ep. πτῆξα Il. 14.40: aor. 2 ἔπτᾰκον in compd. καταπτακών A. Eu. 252; Ep. 3 dual καταπτήτην Il. 8.136: pf. ἔπτηχα Isoc. 5.58, ( κατ-) Lycurg. 40, D. 4.8; later ἔπτηκα ( κατ-) Them. Or. 24.309b; Ep. part. πεπτηώς, ῶτος (v.infr. II.2).

children.label: I
children.definition: scare, alarm, πτῆξε θυμὸν ἐνὶ στήθεσσιν Ἀχαιῶν Il. 14.40; ἐχθροὺς πτῆξαι Thgn. 1015.

children.label: II
children.definition: crouch or cower for fear, of animals, ἅπερ πτηνῶν ἀγέλαι τάχʼ ἂν σιγῇ πτήξειαν ἄφωνοι S. Aj. 171 (anap.); πτήξας δέμας παρεῖχε A. Pers. 209; [ πῶλος] π. αἰσχύνῃσιν S. Fr. 659.9, cf. Ar. Av. 777; of human beings, ἔπταξαν ἀκίνητοι σιωπᾷ Pi. P. 4.57; ὑπὸ φόβῳ π. E. Ba. 1035 (lyr.); πτῆξαι ταπεινήν Id. Andr. 165; π. θυμόν S. OC 1466 (lyr.); κακῶς πάσχων π. Pl. Smp. 184b; δοκεῖ μοι τοῦ αὐτοῦ ἀνδρὸς εἶναι καὶ εὐτυχοῦντα ἐξυβρίσαι καὶ πταίσαντα . . πτῆξαι X. Cyr. 3.1.26; ἐκποδὼν π. Ar. Th. 36: with Preps., π. ἐν μυχοῖς πέτρας E. Cyc. 408; εἰς ἕνα χῶρον Ar. Lys. 770; πόλις πρὸς πόλιν π. E. Supp. 269; βωμὸν ὄρνις ὣς ἔπτηξʼ ὕπο Id. HF 974: c. acc. loci, βωμὸν π. Id. Ion 1280.

data.quote: ἅπερ πτηνῶν ἀγέλαι τάχʼ ἂν σιγῇ πτήξειαν ἄφωνοι
δοκεῖ μοι τοῦ αὐτοῦ ἀνδρὸς εἶναι καὶ εὐτυχοῦντα ἐξυβρίσαι καὶ πταίσαντα . . πτῆξαι

children.definition: crouch, of men in ambush, νῷν εἰς ἐρημίαν ὁδοῦ Id. Andr. 753; ὑπὸ τεύχεσι πεπτηῶτες Od. 14.474.

crouch for fear of . . , ἀπειλάς A. Pr. 175 (anap.); φοβούμενοι πτήσσομεν αὐτούς X. Cyr. 3.3.18; ταῖς διανοίαις μὴ πτήξαντες τὸν τῶν ἐπιόντων φόβον Lycurg. 49; δόρυ Lyc. 280, IG 14.1296: abs., ὁ λέων . . ὁρώμενος . . οὐδέποτε φεύγει οὐδὲ πτήσσει Arist. HA 629b13.

data.quote: ταῖς διανοίαις μὴ πτήξαντες τὸν τῶν ἐπιόντων φόβον
ὁ λέων . . ὁρώμενος . . οὐδέποτε φεύγει οὐδὲ πτήσσει

children.definition: able to fly, τὰ π. strong fliers, Arist. HA 504b8, cf. 614a32; τὸ π. Id. PA 693b13; βάρεα ( βραχέα codd. Ath.) καὶ μὴ π. Thphr. Fr. 180. Adv. -κῶς Plu. Pyth. 2.405b.
πτῐλοβάφος [ ᾰ], ὁ, = plumarius, Gloss. ( ψιλ- - codd.).

definition: πτίλον [ῐ], Dor. ψίλον (q.v.), τό: ( πέτομαι, πτέσθαι):

children.definition: soft feathers or down under the true feathers ( πτίλα· πτερὰ ἁπαλά, Hsch., cf. Phot., Suid.), π. κύκνειον [ S.] Fr. 1127.3, cf. Clytus 1, Ael. NA 12.4, etc.; κνεφάλλων ἢ πτίλων σεσαγμένος Pl.Com. 97, cf. Eub. 5; burned in order to spread pungent smoke, Plb. 21.28.12; down on a youthʼs chin, D.H. Dem. 51.
plume of a helmet, φέρε νῦν ἀπὸ τοῦ κράνους μοι τὸ πτερόν. Ans. τουτὶ πτίλον σοι Ar. Ach. 585, cf. 588; π. τὸ μέγα κομπολακύθου ib. 1182.

children.label: II
children.definition: wing, prop. of insects, Arist. IA 713a10; of the wing-like membrane in a kind of serpents, π. οὐ πτερωτά Hdt. 2.76.

children.label: III
children.definition: anything like a feather or wing,
leaf, Nic. Th. 524.
sails of a ship, Lyc. 25.
with downy back, κάμπη AP 9.256 ( Antiphan.).
suffering from πτίλωσις II, π. τοὺς ὀφθαλμούς LXX Le. 21.20; π. alone, Gal. 10.1017, 12.799; also π. βλέφαρα Dsc. 1.69.3: πτίλλος, = lippus, Gloss.
furnish with feathers, πτηνὰ ἐπτίλωσε (sc. ἡ φύσις) Herm. ap. Stob. 1.49.69:— Pass., to have wings, ἐπτιλῶσθαι Philostr. VA 3.48.
Ael. NA 16.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: a disease of the eyelids in which their edges become swollen and inflamed, and the eyelashes fall off, Gal. 10.1004, Aët. 7.80.
have sore eyes, Archyt. ap. Simp. in Cat. 395.35.
winged, esp. πτιλωτά, opp. πτερωτά, δερμόπτερα, membrane-winged creatures, Arist. HA 490a6.
stuffed with feathers, of a cushion, Poll. 6.10.
peeled barley, Nicopho 15; πτισάνης χυλός Hp. Acut. 6.

children.label: II
children.definition: barley-gruel, π. παχεῖα, opp. χυλός (barleywater), ib. 7, 10; both opp. ποτόν, ib. 68; πτισάνην ἕψειν Ar. Fr. 159, cf. 412, Alex. 142.3, PCair.Zen. 710.76 (iii B.C.).
one who shells or peels, dub.l. in AP 11.351.6 ( Pall.); πτιστής Scaliger.

definition: πτίσανον, τό, poet. for πτισάνη, Nic. Th. 590.

children.definition: drinking of gruel, Hp. Acut. 16.
winnowing of grain, Gal. 19.115: pl., Gp. 2.34.1.
peeled or winnowed grain, Str. 17.1.34.
winnowing, προσαυλεῖν πτισμόν to sing a winnowing-song, Nicopho 17.

definition: πτίσσω, Pherecr. 183, Ar. Fr. 339, Att. πτίττω ib. 271 (prob. l.), Luc. Herm. 79, v.l. in Pherecr. l.c.: aor. ἔπτῐσα Hdt. 2.92:— Pass., aor. ἐπτίσθην Gp. 12.23.2, ( περι-) Thphr. HP 4.4.10: pf. ἔπτισμαι Hp. VM 14, Arist. HA 595b10:—

children.definition: winnow grain, Hp. l.c. ( Pass.), Pherecr. l.c., etc.; πτισσουσῶν ᾠδή the song of women winnowing, Ar. Fr. 339.

children.label: II
children.definition: bray in a mortar, τὸ ἐκ μέσου τοῦ λωτοῦ Hdt. l.c., cf. D.L. 9.59, Luc. l.c. (Cf. Lat. pinso, Skt. pináṣṭi ‘pound’.)
one must winnow, ζειάς, σῖτον, Gp. 3.7.1,8.

definition: πτιστής, οῦ, ὁ, cj. for πτισάνης (q.v.).

children.definition: fitted for winnowing, πτιστικὸν τερετίζειν Phryn.Com. 14.

definition: πτοέω and πτοιέω, fut. -ήσω AP 7.214 ( Arch.): Ep. aor. ἐπτοίησα, Aeol. ἐπτόαισα (v. infr.):— Pass., Ep. aor. ἐπτοιήθην Call. Dian. 191: pf. ἐπτόημαι, Ep. ἐπτοίημαι (v. infr.):—

children.definition: terrify, scare, AP l.c.:— Pass., to be scared, dismayed, φρένες ἐπτοίηθεν Od. 22.298; ἐξ ὕπνου κέκραγεν ἐπτοημένη A. Ch. 535; ἐπτοημένας δεινοῖς δράκουσιν by serpents, E. El. 1255 (s. v.l.); ἔβαλλε χεῖρας ἐπτοημένας Id. Tr. 559 (lyr.); πτοηθεὶς ἐπὶ τοῖς ἠγγελμένοις Plb. 31.11.4, cf. LXX Ex. 19.16, al., Ev.Luc. 21.9, 24.37; περὶ ὃ ἂν τύχῃ Polystr. p.29 W.; of animals, Q.S. 11.48, 13.457.

children.label: II
children.definition: flutter, excite by any passion, τό μοι καρδίαν . . ἐπτόαισεν Sapph. 2.6, cf. eand. Supp. 14.6; τὴν δὲ φρένας ἐπτοίησεν Κύπρις A.R. 1.1232; Κύπρις ἐπʼ Αἰακίδῃ κούρῃ φρένας ἐπτοίησεν Poet. ap. Parth. 21.2:— Pass., to be passionately excited, Mimn. 5.2 (= Thgn. 1018); ἐπτοημένοι φρένας A. Pr. 856; ὡς ἐπτόηται E. Ba. 214, cf. IA 1029; ἔρωτι ἐπτοάθης ib. 586 (lyr.); πτοιηθεὶς ὑπʼ ἔρωτι Call. l.c.; τὸ περὶ τὰς ἐπιθυμίας μὴ ἐπτοῆσθαι Pl. Phd. 68c, cf. R. 439d, Epicur. Fr. 465; περὶ τὴν ὀχείαν Arist. HA 614a26, cf. 571b10; περὶ τὰ ὄψα Plu. Lat.viv. 2.1128b; περὶ τὸ κέρδος Onos. 1.20; ἐς γυναῖκας Luc. Am. 5; ἐπὶ τὸ νέον ib. 23; ἐπὶ γυναικί Parth. 4.2; πρὸς τὰς αἶγας Plu. Bruta anim. 2.989a; τῇ γνώμῃ πρὸς τὸν πόλεμον Id. Sull. 7; to be distraught, μεθʼ ὁμήλικας ἐπτοίηται he gapes like one distraught after his fellows, Hes. Op. 447; τὸ πτοηθέν distraction, E. Ba. 1268. ( πτοι- only in dactylic verse, perh. metri gr.; the -άω inflexion only in Thgn. l.c., E. IA 586 (lyr.); Lesb. -αις ( ε) may have -αι- for -η- as αἰμίονος, etc.)

data.quote: τὸ περὶ τὰς ἐπιθυμίας μὴ ἐπτοῆσθαι

definition: πτόησις, or πτοίησις (so in Pl.), εως, ἡ,

children.definition: vehement emotion or excitement, Pl. Prt. 310d; περί τι Id. Smp. 206d; ἡ τοῦ σώματος π. Id. Cra. 404a, cf. Arist. GA 774a5 (dub.), Clearch. (?) ap. Ath. 15.670c, Agatharch. 5, Ph. 1.509; μὴ φοβούμεναι μηδεμίαν πτόησιν 1 Ep.Pet. 3.6.

definition: πτοητός, only in the form πτοιητός, ή, όν,

children.definition: scared, Nic. Al. 243, Max. 164.

definition: πτοία, Ep. πτοίη Opp. H. 3.431, Nic. Al. 212: rarely πτόα, EM 695.1, v.l. in Ph. 1.531; and πτόη, LXX 1 Ma. 3.25, 3 Ma. 6.17: ἡ: ( πτοέω):—

children.definition: terror, fright, Onos. 6.5; παραχὴ καὶ π. Plu. Fab. 11, cf. Ph. 2.204, al.; ἀμυδραὶ καὶ φαντασιώδεις π. Philostr. VA 7.14, cf. Plb. 1.39.14, 1.68.6.

children.label: II
children.definition: excitement, πάθος ἐστὶ πτοία ψυχῆς Zeno Stoic. 1.51, cf. Chrysipp. ib. 3.127; π. περὶ τὰ ἀφροδίσια, εἰς ἀφρ., Epicur. Fr. 458, Ael. NA 10.27; ἡ περὶ φιλοσοφίαν π. Procl. in Alc. p.43C., cf. Plu. Profect. 2.83d: pl., Ti.Locr. 103b.
scared, Opp. H. 3.431.

definition: πτοιέω, πτοίησις, πτοιητός, v. πτοέω, πτόησις, πτοητός. πτοίνα, v. κτοίνα. πτοῖος, ὁ, = πτοία, Hsch. (s.v.l.).

children.definition: scared, shy, Hp. Epid. 6.2.20, cf. Erot.; ὁρμαί, ἄγνοια, Stoic. 3.166.

definition: Πτολεμαεῖον, τό, precinct dedicated to the Ptolemies at Rhodes, D.S. 20.100.

Πτολεμαῖα, τά, festival at Athens, IG 2(2).891.14; at Alexandria, IG 5(2).118.12 ( Tegea, iii B.C.); at Delos, Πτολεμαίεια Inscr.Délos 320 B 60 (iii B.C.); also Πτολεμαίεα, ib. 57; of a festival in the island of Hiera, PSI 4.364 (iii B.C.).

children.definition: of Ptolemy or the Ptolemies, ὅπλα LXX 3 Ma. 1.2; νόμισμα BGU 713.23 (i A.D.), Poll. 9.85: hence Πτολεμαϊκά, τά, Ptolemaic coins, IG 7.303.91 (Orop.).
οἱ Π. βασιλεῖς kings of the Ptolemaic dynasty, Str. 2.5.12.

definition: Πτολεμαῖος, ὁ, Ptolemy, name of the Kings of Egypt in the period after Alexander: also of a month at Methymna, dub. in IG 12 (2).500.

children.definition: φυλή, name of an Att. tribe, named after Ptolemy Euergetes I, IG 2(2).957.28, 964.16, al., Poll. 8.110; ἐπὶ τῆς Πτολεμαιίδος . . πρυτανείας IG 2(2).897, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: Acre, Str. 2.5.39, etc.:— Πτολεμ-ᾱΐτης, ου, or Πτολεμ-αιεύς, έως, ὁ, a citizen thereof, St.Byz.

definition: πτολεμίζω, πτολεμιστής, πτόλεμόνδε, Ep. for πολεμ-.
πτολίαρχος, Ep. for πολίαρχος, Call. Jov. 73; also Πτολεμ-άρχης, ου, ὁ, Epigr.Gr. 1036 ( Nicomedia).
πτολίεθρον [ ῐ], τό, Ep. lengthd. form for πόλις ( πτόλις), Il. 2.133, Od. 1.2, Hes. Sc. 81, etc.

children.definition: dweller in the city, on Cretan coins, BMus.Cat. Coins Crete p.8 ( Aptera, iv B.C.).

definition: πτολιπόρθιος, ον, = sq., of Odysseus, Od. 9.504.

children.definition: sacking or wasting cities, epith. of Ares, Il. 20.152, Hes. Th. 936; of Odysseus and Oïleus, Il. 2.278, 728; of Achilles, 15.77, etc.; also of Heracles, Tab.Defix. in Stud.Ital. 2(1922).394 (Cret., iv/iii B.C.); π. μάχαι Pi. O. 8.35; πτολίπορθον στίχα Μήδων Epigr. ap. D.S. 11.14:— also πτολι-πόρθης, ου, ὁ, A. Ag. 472 (lyr.); as pr.n. of a son of Odysseus, Paus. 8.12.6:—the form πολίπορθος never occurs, for πτολίπορθʼ (voc.) is rightly restored in A. Ag. 783 (lyr.); cf. sq. [πτόλις]

Il. 2.130, etc. (not Aeol., but an Epicism in Sapph. 44.12 L.-P.); also in Trag. (not S.) lyr., A. Th. 114, 843, E. Tr. 556, (in dialogue) A. Th. 6, Eu. 79, E. Hec. 767, Andr. 699; found in Cypr., Inscr.Cypr. 135.1 H., cf. Heraclid. ap. Eust. 842.63, Sch. Il. 23.1; also Arc. as the old name of Mantinea, Paus. 8.12.7; once in Ion. Prose, Hp. Medic. 14; in ll. cc. only nom. and acc. sg. ( πτόλις, πτόλιν) are found; gen. sg. πτόλεως Hermesian. 7.72 cod.; Cypr. dat. sg. πτόλιϝι Inscr.Cypr. 135.6H.—Expld. by ναῦγος ἢ πόλις, Hsch.
Phot., Suid.
with spinous shoots, Thphr. HP 6.1.3.
Nic. Al. 267.

definition: πτόρθιος, ὁ, epith. of Poseidon, IG 1(2).190.16.

children.definition: young branch, shoot, sucker, sapling, Od. 6.128; ὥς τις π. ηὐξόμην E. Hec. 20; πτόρθοισι δάφνης Id. Ion 103 (anap.); μαλάχης Ar. Pl. 544; οἱ π. καὶ οἱ νέοι κλῶνες Pl. Prt. 334b, cf. Thphr. CP 5.1.3; πτόρθους ἁπαλοὺς ἀποτρώγουσαι Eup. 14.2: generally, branch, Arist. PA 687a2, etc.; π. μέγας, of Heracles’ club, APl. 16.103 ( Tull.Gem.).

data.quote: οἱ π. καὶ οἱ νέοι κλῶνες

children.label: II
children.definition: sprouting, budding, Hes. Op. 421.

definition: πτορθοφορέω, cj. for πρωτοφορέω in Ath. 13.565f.
πτόρμος, ὁ, Aeol. for πταρμός, Jo.Gramm. Comp. 3.47.

children.definition: salivate, Hp. Prorrh. 1.31 ( -ελ-), Coac. 555 ( -αλ-).
salivation, Hp. Prog. 17 ( -ελ-), Acut. ( Sp.) 40 ( -αλ-), al.

sputum, saliva, Hp. Aph. 1.12 ( -ελ-), Prog. 15 ( -ελ-), Acut. 66 ( -αλ-), al., Arist. HA 607a30, GA 747a10:—also πτύελος, ὁ, Id. EE 1235a38, LXX Jb. 7.19, Hsch. s.v. σίαλος.—The forms in πτυαλ- and πτυελ- are found in codd. of Hp. (v. Kuehlewein i p.cvi) and of later writers; in those of Arist. the latter only is found.
secreting saliva freely, Diogenian. 8.71.
like spittle, Hp. Coac. 571 ( -αλ-).

definition: πτυάριον, τό, Dim. of πτύον, Hdn. Epim. 117, EM 562.43.

children.definition: spitter, a kind of asp, Hierocl. p.11 A., Gal. 14.235, Philum. Ven. 16, interpol. in Porph. Abst. 3.9.
fold or anything folded, πέπλοιο π. Il. 5.315, cf. AP 6.271 ( Phaedim.); π. τοῦ δέρματος fold of skin, Antyll. ap. Orib. 45.15.8; τῆς ὑστέρας, = fundus uteri, Paul.Aeg. 3.64.

children.label: II
children.definition: piece of lint folded up to stop a wound, pledget, Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.13.27; of a bandage, Gal. 18(1).826.

definition: πτυγμάτιον, τό, Dim. of foreg. [πτύγμα] II, Heliod. ap. Orib. 44.10.17, Sor. 1.82, Leonid. ap. Aët. 7.71.

children.definition: eagle-owl, = ὕβρις, dub. l. in Arist. HA 615b11.

definition: πτυελίζω, πτυελ-ισμός, πτύελ-ον, πτυελ-ώδης, v. πτυαλίζω, etc.
πτυΐδιον, τό, Dim. of πτύον, Sch. Ar. Av. 1150.

children.definition: folded, πίναξ π. folding tablet, Il. 6.169, cf. Aristid. Or. 17(15).22 (pl.), Hdn. 7.6.5 (pl.).
capable of being folded or doubled up, κλῖμαξ, πύργος, App. Hisp. 94, BC 5.36.

children.label: II
children.definition: πτυκτόν, τό, folded bandage, Paul.Aeg. 6.90.

definition: πτύξ, ἡ (nom. only Gramm., Hdn.Gr. 1.396, Hsch.), dat. πτῠχί Il. 20.22: pl. πτύχες, πτύχας, 7.247, al., Hes. Sc. 143, etc.: after Hom. πτῠχή, ῆς, which prevails in Pi. (v. infr. II) and Trag.; the metre requires acc. sg. πτύχα in E. Supp. 979 (lyr.), but acc. pl. πτυχάς in S. Fr. 144; in other places either πτύχας or πτυχάς will suit the metre:—

children.definition: layer, plate, mostly in pl., σάκεος πτύχες plates of metal or leather, in strong shields, Il. 18.481, cf. 7.247, 20.269, Hes. Sc. 143.

fold ( i.e. folded piece) of a garment, in pl., first in h.Cer. 176, then in S. Fr. 494, E. Supp. 979 (lyr.); of the entrails, κατὰ σπλάγχνων πτυχάς ib. 212; εἰς τὰς πτυχάς Arist. HA 549a17; coats of the stomach, Gal. 2.556; layers of muscles, Id. 18(2).944.
tablets, ἐν πτυχαῖς βίβλων κατεσφραγισμένα A. Supp. 947; γραμμάτων πτυχὰς ἔχων S. Fr. 144; ἐν δέλτου πτυχαῖς E. IA 98, cf. IG 9 (1).880.10 (Corc.).

children.label: II
children.definition: folds, glens, κατὰ πτύχας Οὐλύμποιο Il. 11.77; πτύχες ἠνεμόεσσαι (from the wind that rushes down narrow mountain-clefts), Od. 19.432; also in sg., πτυχὶ Οὐλύμποιο, Παρνησοῖο, Il. 20.22, h.Ap. 269, h.Merc. 555; πτυχαὶ Κρισαῖαι, Πίνδου, Πέλοπος, Pi. P. 6.18, 9.15, N. 2.21; ἐν Κιθαιρῶνος πτυχαῖς S. OT 1026, cf. E. Supp. 757, Ba. 62, Andr. 1277; Αὐλίδος κατὰ πτυχάς Id. IT 1082, cf. 9: also of the sky, πτυχαὶ αἰθέρος, οὐρανοῦ, Id. Or. 1631, Hel. 44, Ph. 84: sg., μέχρις οὐρανοῦ πτυχός Ezek. Exag. 69.

children.label: III
children.definition: ὕμνων πτυχαί folds of song, i.e. sinuous songs, Pi. O. 1.105.

children.label: IV
children.definition: πτυχάς or πτύχας leaves of a folding door, metaph., ὁ κλείσας οὐρανοῦ δισσὰς π. PMag.Par. 1.190; nom. πτύχες, = θύραι, σανίδες, Poll. 10.24.

children.label: V
children.definition: πτυχή, ἡ, the part of a ship on which her name was inscribed, Sch. A.R. 1.1089; cf. πτυχίς.

definition: πτύξαγρις and πύξαγρις, ὁ, name of the crab

children.definition: which extracts the flesh of the oyster from its shell by putting a small stone between the valves ( πτύχες or πυξία), Zonar.
folding, Hsch., Eust. 633.19; π. ὑστερῶν corrugation, dub. in Hp. Coac. 515.

children.label: II
children.definition: fold, LXX Jb. 41.4(5).

children.label: III
children.definition: Arr. Tact. 9.4 (pl.).
winnowing-shovel, fan, Il. 13.588 (in poet. gen. πτυόφιν), A. Fr. 210, S. Fr. 1084, Theoc. 7.156, Porph. Antr. 35:— πτέον is Att. acc. to Ael.Dion. Fr. 288, Poll. 1.245, etc.
consternation, Hsch. s.v. πτοία ( πτοιρμός cod.), Phot. s.v. πτοίαν, Eust. 795.29.

definition: πτύρομαι [ῡ], aor. 2 ἐπτύρην [ῠ] Plu. Fab. 3, inf. πτυρῆναι Pl. Ax. 370a:— Pass.,

children.definition: to be scared or frightened, Hp. Mul. 1.25; of the soul, M.Ant. 8.45; esp. of horses, shy, start, D.S. 2.19, Plu. l.c.; τινι at a thing, Id. Marc. 6; φωνῇ π. ὥσπερ θηρίον Id. Praec. 2.800c; πρός τι Ph. Bybl. ap. Eus. PE 1.10: c. acc., π. τὸν θάνατον start at, be alarmed at death, Pl. l.c.; ἔν τινι Ep.Phil. 1.28.
timorous, Arist. Mir. 846b35, Str. 6.1.13, Eust.ad D.P. 373.
spitting, αἵματος Hp. Aph. 3.29 (pl.), Arist. Ph. 243b13, etc.
sputum, Hp. Aph. 5.11: more freq. in pl., Id. Acut. 42, Coac. 401, Plb. 8.12.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: venom, Porph. Abst. 3.9.
Hp. Epid. 7.25.

definition: πτύσσω (never πτύττω), ( ἀνα-) S. Fr. 301: fut. πτύξω ( ἀνα-) E. HF 1256: aor. ἔπτυξα (v. infr.):— Med., Od. 2.77 ( ποτι-), etc.: fut. πτύξομαι ( προσ-) 3.22: aor. ἐπτυξάμην Ar. Nu. 267:— Pass., Il. 13.134, etc.: aor. ἐπτύχθην ( ἀν-, δι-) X. Cyr. 7.5.5, S. Ant. 709: aor. 2 ἐπτύγην [ῠ], ( ἀν-) Hp. Int. 48: pf. ἔπτυγμαι App. BC 4.72, etc., ( ἀν-) E. El. 357; πέπτυκται Arist. HA 536a11: plpf. ἔπτυκτο ( προσ-) Pi. I. 2.39:—

children.definition: fold, double up, χιτῶνα, εἵματα πτύξαι, fold up garments and put them by, Od. 1.439, 6.111, 252; σπλῆνα Hp. Fract. 8; χεῖρας πτύξαι ἐπί τινι fold oneʼs arms over or round another, S. OC 1611; βιβλίον fold, close a book, Ev.Luc. 4.20.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., of the foetus, Hp. Mul. 1.69; of bandages, Gal. 18(1).826; γραμματεῖα ἐπτυγμένα Hdn. 1.17.1; πύργοι ἐπτ. App. l.c.; ἔγχεα δὲ πτύσσοντο perh. were interlaced, Il. l.c.
fold or cling round, χιτὼν . . ἀμφὶ μηρὸν πτύσσεται S. Fr. 872.3 (lyr.).

children.label: III
children.definition: Med., fold round oneself, wrap round one, τι Ar. Nu. 267.
Phot.; πτύοχλον (leg. πτύσχλον), = ὑπόδημα ἀνδρεῖον, Hsch.: cf. ἕπτυσχλοι (quod fort. legend.).
folding tablet, Hdn.Gr. 1.356, PMag.Lond. 121.740, Zen. 5.82.

children.label: II
children.definition: pendant of an ear-ring, PLond. 5.1719.15 (vi A.D.).
slab, in sg. as collective, μαρμάρων πτυχίς Procop.Gaz. Ecphr. p.151B.; = ἀκροστόλιον, the part of a ship on which the name was inscribed, Poll. 1.86; cf. πτύξ v.
in folds or layers, Arist. HA 541b27.

definition: πτύω, Il. 23.697, etc.: fut. πτύσω [ῠ] Hp. Prorrh. 2.40; πτύσομαι Id. Morb. 1.28: aor. ἔπτῠσα ib. 22, S. Ant. 653, etc.: pf. ἔπτῠκα S.E. M. 8.252, Gal. 10.374, 11.281:— Pass., fut. πτυσθήσομαι ( ἀνα-) Id. 9.686, 15.700, ( ἐμ-) Ev.Luc. 18.32: aor. ἐπτύσθην Hp. Morb. 1.28: aor.2 part. πτυέντα Id. Epid. 2.3.4. [ ῡ in pres. and impf.; later Ep. have ῠ in impf. before a short syll., Nonn. D. 10.171, but mostly in compds., ( ἀνα-) A.R. 2.570, ( ἀπο-) 4.925, ( ἐξ-) Theoc. 24.19; ῠ always in aor.): —

children.definition: spit out or up, αἷμα Il. l.c., Hp. Art. 49: abs., spit, Hdt. 1.99, X. Cyr. 8.1.42: c. dat., πτύσας προσώπῳ spat in his face, S. Ant. 1232.

disgorge, cast out, με . . τηλόσʼ ἀπὸ . . ἠϊόνος AP 7.283 ( Leon.), cf. Opp. H. 5.596: metaph., στοργὰν ἔπτυσας εἰς ἀνέμους AP 7.468 ( Mel.): abs., ἐπʼ ἀϊόνι πτύοντα, of waves, Theoc. 15.133; ἱστὸς ὄλισθεν εἰς ἅλα πτύσας with a splash, AP 9.290 ( Phil.).

children.label: b
children.definition: spawn, Babr. 6.8.

children.label: c
children.definition: πρὶν πτύσαι ‘before you can say Jack Robinson’, Men. Pk. 202.
πτύσας with loathing, S. Ant. 653; ἰδεῖν ῥᾷόν ἐστι καὶ πτύσαι Epicr. 3.20.

εἰς κόλπον π., to avert a bad omen, disarm magic, etc., which was done three times, ὡς μὴ βασκανθῶ δὲ τρὶς εἰς ἐμὸν ἔπτυσα κόλπον Theoc. 6.39, cf. 20.11; φρίξας εἰς κόλπον πτύσαι Thphr. Char. 16.15, cf. Luc. Nav. 15, etc.; ὑπὸ κόλπον π. AP 12.229 ( Strat.).

data.quote: ὡς μὴ βασκανθῶ δὲ τρὶς εἰς ἐμὸν ἔπτυσα κόλπον

children.label: II
children.definition: promote the flow of spittle, of certain wines, in Pass., Hp. Vict. 2.52. (Cf. Goth. speiwan ‘spit’, Lat. spuo, etc.)

definition: Πτωϊεύς, έως, ὁ, = sq., IG 7.2729 (Acraeph.), al.

children.definition: IG 7.2712: τὰ Πτώϊα the festival of Apollo Πτώϊος, ib. 2170, al.
timorous, πτωκάσιν αἰθυίῃσι Hom. Epigr. 8.2; π. κύπειρος crouching, low, Simm. 12.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., timorous ones, i.e. birds, S. Ph. 1093 (lyr., dub.l.).
fall, πεσεῖν . . πτώματʼ οὐκ ἀνασχετά A. Pr. 919; πίπτουσι . . πτώματʼ αἰσχρά S. Ant. 1046; π. θανάσιμον πεσῇ E. El. 686; ἡ πόλις οὐκ ἂν ἔπεσε τοιοῦτον π. Pl. La. 181b.

children.label: b
children.definition: fall in wrestling, Call. Iamb. 1.274, AP 9.391 ( Diotim.): metaph., booby-trap, π. φιλοσόφων ἀπαλαιστρότατον Phld. Rh. 1.8S.; lapse, blunder, Gal. 10.124.
misfortune, calamity, τά γʼ ἐκ θεῶν πτώματα calamities sent by the gods, E. HF 1228.
injuries due to falls, bruises, Dsc. 1.128,3.1,5.117.

children.label: II
children.definition: fallen body, corpse, carcase, freq. with gen., πτῶμα Ἑλένης, Ἐτεοκλέους, E. Or. 1196, Ph. 1697, cf. LXX Jd. 14.8, D.H. 4.70, etc.; πτώματα νεκρῶν E. Ph. 1482 (anap.): without a gen., A. Supp. 662 (s. v.l., lyr.), Plb. 15.14.2, Sardis 7 No. 165, Plu. Alex. 33, etc.: collective in sg., SIG 700.17 (Maced., ii B.C.), Apoc. 11.8, Polyaen. 6.18.1.

ruin, οἰκίας, κρηνῖδος, IG ΙΙ(2).161 A 120, 163 Ba 21 ( Delos, iii B.C.); ἐπὶ τοῦ π. on the ruins (of the wall), Plb. 16.31.8, cf. 5.4.9, 5.100.6, Aristid. Or. 25(43).27; breach in a city-wall, D.S. 16.8, al.: pl., ruins, IG 11(2).199 A 103 ( Delos, iii B.C.), Ph. Bel. 100.45, Plb. 21.28.2; π. οἴκων Phryn. 351; π. ἐλαιῶν fallen olive-trees or fruit, Lys. Fr. 203 S.; windfall fruit, of the φοῖνιξ, Dsc. 1.109.

children.label: III
children.definition: payment which falls due, PEleph. 11.4 ( iii B.C., pl.), PLond. 1.3.37 (ii B.C.).
make to fall, Aq. De. 25.2, al., Tab.Defix.Aud. 16 ( Syria, iii A.D.):— Pass., οἱ πτωματιζόμενοι those who have the falling sickness, epileptics, Apollon. Mir. 36, Paul.Al. L. 4.

children.label: II
children.definition: fall or be ready to fall, IG 2(2).463.47, Theano Ep. 4.3.
subject to epilepsy, Vett.Val. 113.1; -κά, τά, = πτωματισμοί, Procl. Par.Ptol. 215.
Dim. of πτῶμα II, corpse, CIG 2801 ( Aphrodisias).
tumbler, i.e. cup that will not stand upright, and therefore must be emptied at once, Mosch. ap. Ath. 11.485e.
epilepsy, Ptol. Tetr. 153, Cat.Cod.Astr. 2.179 (pl., but in both places perh. distinguished from epilepsy).
cowering animal, i.e. hare, Il. 17.676, Thphr. HP 4.3.5, Theoc. 1.110; also πτῶκα λαγωόν Il. 22.310, cf. Babr. 102.10: metaph. of a person, A. Eu. 326.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., cowering, πτῶκα δʼ ἐν κλόνῳ δορός Lyc. 944.
having fallen, fallen, στρατός A. Ag. 639; σταγών ib. 1122 (lyr.).

falling, fall, κύβων Pl. R. 604c, cf. Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.282 (pl.); κεραυνῶν Arist. Mete. 339a3, Plu. QPlat. 2.1005b (pl.); Φαέθοντος Plb. 2.16.13: metaph., π. τῆς ψυχῆς, opp. ἔπαρσις, Zeno Stoic. 1.51 (pl.): abs., calamity, ἐν καιρῷ πτώσεως LXX Si. 3.31, cf. Ex. 30.12; πτώσεις ἀνθρώπων Orph. Fr. 251, al.; death, Lyd. Ost. 12, 14, 20.

children.label: II
children.definition: mode or modification of a word, Arist. Po. 1457a18, al.; applied to cases, including nom., ib. 20, Int. 16b1: to genders, Id. SE 173b27: to Sup. of Adjs., Id. Top. 136b30: to Advbs., ib. 15, Rh. 1397a20: to Adjs. derived fr. nouns, e.g. χαλκοῦς, ib. 1410a32: to tenses (exc. the pres.), Id. Int. 16b17: so by the Stoics to variety of flexion, Stoic. 3.263, but most freq. to cases of the Noun, περὶ τῶν πέντε π., title of work by Chrysipp., cf. D.T. 634.16, etc.; κατὰ μίαν πτῶσιν indeclinable, A.D. Adv. 165.10.

children.label: III
children.definition: Arist., mood of syllogisms, APr. 42b30.

children.label: b
children.definition: arrangement of terms in a syllogism, Id. APo. 94a12.
crouch or cower for fear, Il. 4.372.

shrink from, shrink, of birds or other animals, π. ὥστε πέρδικα Archil. 106; [ ἀκρίδες] πτώσσουσι καθʼ ὕδωρ flee into . ., Il. 21.14; also of men, πτῶσσον ὑπὸ κρημνούς ib. 26; τί πτώσσεις; 4.371; τίς τοι ἀνάγκη πτώσσειν . . ; 5.634; πτώσσοντας ὑφʼ Ἕκτορι 7.129; κατὰ λαύρας . . πτώσσοντι skulk, slink, Pi. P. 8.87; εἰς ἐρημίαν π. flee cowering into . ., E. Ba. 223; π. ὑπʼ ἀσπίδος crouch beneath it, without any notion of fear, Tyrt. 11.36:—poet. Verb, once in Hdt., πτώσσοντας [ὑμέας εὕρομεν] 9.48.
cringe like a beggar, go begging (cf. πτωχός) , κατὰ δῆμον Od. 17.227, 18.363: c. acc. loci, π. ἀλλοτρίους οἴκους Hes. Op. 395.

children.label: II
children.definition: οὐδʼ ἂν (v.l. ἂρ) ἔτι δὴν ἀλλήλους πτώσσοιμεν we can no longer shirk one another, Il. 20.427; ποῖ καί με φυγᾷ πτώσσουσι μυχῶν; to what corners have they fled to shun me? E. Hec. 1066 (lyr.): c. acc. rei, [ ὄρνιθες] νέφεα πτώσσουσαι shrinking from the clouds, Od. 22.304; π. δόρυ, βροντήν, Q.S. 5.300, 7.531.

capable of inflexion, ἄρθρον ἐστὶ στοιχεῖον λόγου π. Diog.Bab.Stoic. 3.214; ὄνομά ἐστι μέρος λόγου π. D.T. 634.11, cf. A.D. Pron. 9.5, al.; τὸ π. τὸ Σωκράτης" the case-form Σ., S.E. M. 8.84; connected with cases, π. σχῆμα, when several cases of the same Noun follow one another, Simp. in Cat. 359.9. Adv. -κῶς, ἀντωνυμίαι κάτωθεν μὲν π. κινοῦνται ἄνωθεν δὲ προσωπικῶς Choerob. in Theod. 2.418 H.

data.quote: -κῶς, ἀντωνυμίαι κάτωθεν μὲν π. κινοῦνται ἄνωθεν δὲ προσωπικῶς

children.definition: πτωτικόν, τό, special case of a problem, Papp. 850.19, al.
apt to fall, fallen, Hdn.Gr. 2.943, Hsch.
braggart beggar, of Midias, Phryn.Com. 4, cf. Ath. 6.230c.
beggary, mendicity, ἐς πτωχηΐην ἀπῖκται Hdt. 3.14; εἰς ἐσχάτην π. ἐλθεῖν Pl. Lg. 936b; εἰς π. καταστάντες Lys. 32.10: pl., Pl. R. 618a: prov., πτωχείας πενία ἀδελφή Ar. Pl. 549.

children.label: II
children.definition: poor relief, Cod.Just. 1.3.41.23. -εῖον, τό, poorhouse, ib. 1.2.15.1 (pl.), Procop. Aed. 5.9, EM 187.22; written πτωχῖον, MAMA 3.783; Lat. ptochium, Cod.Just. 1.3.48.1.
beggar-Helen, i.e. prostitute, Ath. 13.585b.

definition: πτωχεύω, fut. -σω Od. 15.309: Ep. impf. πτωχεύεσκον 18.2:—

children.definition: to be a beggar, go begging, Il.cc.; ἀνὰ δῆμον 19.73, cf. Tyrt. 10.4, Ar. Nu. 921 (anap.), etc.; ἐπὶ ξενίας Antipho 2.2.9.
to be as poor as a beggar, Antiph. 322, Pl. Erx. 394b.
to be badly off for, πραγμάτων, of historians, Plb. 7.7.6.

children.label: II
children.definition: beg ( for), δαῖτα Od. 17.11, 19.
ask an alms of, φίλους Thgn. 922.
make poor, Κύριος πτωχίζει καὶ πλουτίζει LXX 1 Ki. 2.7.
of or fit for a beggar, beggarly, στολή E. Rh. 503, Lycurg. 86; ἐπιθυμίαι Pl. R. 554c; π. βακτήριον a beggarʼs staff, Ar. Ach. 448; ὀνόματα π. fit for beggars, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 22.
living (or rather starving) by his wits, κόλαξ Gorg. Fr. 15 ( πτωχομουσοκόλακας cj. Vahlen).
drawing beggarly characters, of a poet, Ar. Ra. 842.
making poor, δικαιοσύνη Plu. Comp.Arist.Cat. 3.

definition: πτωχός, ή, όν, also ός, όν A. Ag. 1274, S. OC 444, 751:—

children.definition: beggar, Od. 14.400, 18.1, Hdt. 3.14, etc.; πρὸς γὰρ Διός εἰσιν ἅπαντες ξεῖνοί τε πτωχοί τε Od. 6.208, cf. 17.475; πτωχὸς πτωχῷ φθονέει Hes. Op. 26; π. ἀνὴρ ἀλαλήμενος ἐλθών Od. 21.327; π. καὶ ἀλήμονες ἄνδρες 19.74; πτωχοὺς ἀλᾶσθαι E. Med. 515; πτωχοῦ βίος ζῆν ἐστιν μηδὲν ἔχοντα, τοῦ δὲ πένητος ζῆν φειδόμενον Ar. Pl. 552: prov., πτωχοῦ πήρη οὐ πίμπλαται Call. Fr. 360: πτωχή beggar-woman, Ath. 10.453a (so πτωχός (fem.), S. OC 444); χήρα πτωχή Ev.Marc. 12.42.

data.quote: πρὸς γὰρ Διός εἰσιν ἅπαντες ξεῖνοί τε πτωχοί τε
πτωχοῦ βίος ζῆν ἐστιν μηδὲν ἔχοντα, τοῦ δὲ πένητος ζῆν φειδόμενον

children.definition: οἱ π. τῷ πνεύματι Ev.Matt. 5.3, cf. Ev.Luc. 6.20.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., beggarly, πτωχῷ διαίτῃ S. OC 751; π. στοιχεῖα Ep.Gal. 4.9: c. gen., beggared of, poor in, [ πηγὴ] π. νυμφῶν AP 9.258 ( Antiphan.).
Comp. πτωχότερος Timocl. 6.10; prov., π. κίγκλου ‘as poor as a church mouse’, Men. 221; irreg. πτωχίστερος Ar. Ach. 425: Sup. πτωχότατος AP 10.50 ( Pall.).
Adv. -χῶς poorly, scantily, ἠροτρία π. μέν, ἀλλʼ ἀναγκαίως Babr. 55.2.
poverty, dub. in Ostr.Strassb. 794.
poorhouse, Cod.Just. 1.2.19, 7.37.3.3 (as Lat. word), Suid.
supporting the poor, Cod.Just. 1.3.41.13, Just. Nov. 120.6.2.
like a beggar, Thd. Pr. 13.7.
a throw of the dice, Eub. 57.4.
Dim. of πύανος, mixture of various kinds of pulse, cooked sweet, Sosib. ap. Ath. 14.648b.
made of beans, πόλτος Alcm. 75 (otherwise expld. by Sosib., v. foreg.).

definition: πύανος [ ῠ], ὁ, = ὁλόπυρος, Heliod.Hist. 3, cf. Poll. 6.61; but Lacon. πούανοι,

children.definition: Hsch.; neut. pl. πύανα, Hp. Mul. 2.113 (one cod.); cf.sq.

definition: Πυανόψια (sc. ἱερά), τά, an Athenian festival in the month Πυανοψιών, in honour of Apollo, Lycurg. Fr. 84: elsewh. written Πυανέψια (cf. sq. [Πυανοψιών]) and expld. fr. πύανον ἕψειν, of a dish of beans cooked and offered, Plu. Thes. 22, Ath. 10.408a, etc.; acc. to Lycurg. l.c. the other Greeks called it Πανόψια ( Πανοψίαν codd.).

Πυανοψιών, ῶνος, ὁ, the fourth month of the Att. year, named from the festival Πυανόψια, corresponding to the latter part of October and former of November, IG 1(2).6.64, 2(2).1014.4, etc.; also at Priene, Miletus, etc., SIG 282.19 (iv B.C.), 588.90 (ii B.C.), etc.: freq. written Πυανεψιών, Thphr. HP 4.2.10, etc.; but not in Att. Inscrr. (exc. Ποιανεψιών IG 2(2).2239.82 (iii A.D.)); cf. Κυανοψιών.
πῦαρ, gen. and dat. not found, τό, = πυός,

children.definition: first milk after calving, beestings, Ael.Dion. Fr. 290 (where πύαρ), Hsch. (where πύας (sic) is glossed πιτύα (leg. πυτία)).
of or on the rump:

children.label: I
children.definition: τὸ π.,= ἡ πυγή, Hp. Art. 57, 78, Arist. HA 620a15: pl., Archipp. 41 (s.v.l.), Sor. 1.102, Dsc. Eup. 2.56, Hsch., Phot.; τὸ π. ἄκρον, of a bird, Hdt. 2.76.

children.label: II
children.definition: πυγαῖα, τά, in Architecture, = σπεῖρα, base of a column, Hsch.

children.label: III
children.definition: Suid.
suffering pain in the buttocks, Democles Pygelensis (?) ap. Str. 14.1.20 (Lobeck; πυγαλίας codd., -αλγής Schneid.).
white-rump, name of a kind of antelope, Hdt. 4.192, LXX De. 14.5, Ael. NA 7.19.

children.label: II
children.definition: eagle, perh. Circus cyaneus, Arist. HA 618b19; opp. ὁ μελάμπυγος, Archil. 189, cf. Lyc. 91 (et ibi Sch.): metaph. of a coward, S. Fr. 1085.

children.label: III
children.definition: dipper, Cinclus aquaticus, Arist. HA 593b5.

definition: πυγεών, ῶνος, ὁ, dub. sens. in Hippon. in PSI 9.1089.2.
πυγή, ῆς, ἡ, heterocl. acc. πῦγα Arist. Phgn. 810b1 ( τὸ πυγή is a barbarism in Ar. Th. 1187):—

children.definition: rump, buttocks, Archil. 91, Ar. Eq. 365, Sor. 2.60, etc.; pl., Luc. Peregr. 17; ποτὶ πυγὰν ἅλλεσθαι to kick up the heels so as to strike the buttock in dancing, dance the fling, a girls’ exercise at Sparta, Ar. Lys. 82, cf. Antyll. ap. Orib. 6.31.2; πρὸς π. πηδῆσαι Hp. Nat.Puer. 13 (cited as πρὸς πυγὰς πηδᾶν by Sor. 1.60).
fat, swelling land, Eust. 310.2.
tail foremost, ὑποχωρεῖν πάλιν π., of certain oxen, Arist. PA 659a20 (nisi leg. παλιμπ.).

children.label: II
children.definition: rump to rump, Id. HA 539b22.

definition: πυγίδιον, τό, Dim. of πυγή, Ar. Ach. 638, Eq. 1368.

children.definition: paedico, Ar. Th. 1120, Theoc. 5.41: 3 pl. impf. ἐπυγίζοσαν Sammelb. 6840 ( Karnak, ii B.C.): pf. πεπύγικα AP 9.317:— Pass., Sammelb. 7452.9.
paedicatio, Theoc. 5.43.

definition: πυγιστί, Adv., dub.sens. in Hippon. in PSI 9.1089.2.
πυγλίον or πυγαῖον, τό, dub. sens., part of an ἀκινάκης, different from λαβή and κολεόν, IG 2(2).1421.30, 1425.77, 1424a.80.

children.definition: fighting with pygmies, Hecat. 328 J.
a πυγμή long or tall, ἀκρόθινα π. κολοσσῷ ἐφαρμόζων Philostr. VS 1.19.2.
dwarfish, Hdt. 3.37, Arist. Pr. 892a12, Phld. Sign. 2.

children.label: II
children.definition: Πυγμαῖοι, οἱ, the Pygmies, a fabulous race of dwarfs on the upper Nile, said to have been warred on and destroyed by cranes, Il. 3.6, Arist. HA 597a6, cf. Hdt. l.c.
practise boxing, be a boxer, Hexam. ap. Hdt. 5.60, A.R. 2.783.
one who fights with the fist, boxer, Od. 8.246, Pi. I. 8(7).68, Luc. JTr. 33.
fist, Hp. Art. 71, E. IT 1368; τῇ π. θενών Ar. V. 1384; πυγμῇ πατάξαι LXX Ex. 21.18, cf. Is. 58.4.

boxing, as an athletic contest, πυγμῇ νικήσαντα Il. 23.669; πυγμὴν νικᾶν E. Alc. 1031; ἄνδρας πυγμὰν ἐνίκα Ὀλύμπια AP 6.256 (Antip.); πυγμᾶς ἄποινα Pi. O. 7.16, cf. 10(11).67; πυγμὴν or τὴν π. ἀσκεῖν, Pl. Lg. 795b, D. 61.24; freq. in Inscrr., e.g. πυγμὴν Ζωΐλος (sc. ἐνίκησε) IG 7.1765 ( Thespiae), etc.

children.label: b
children.definition: fight, π. μονομάχων καὶ θηρίων Edict.Caes. ap. J. AJ 14.10.6, cf. Artem. 5.58; εἰς π. καθίστασθαι, τρέπεσθαι, of partridges, Gp. 14.20.1,2.
Ev.Marc. 7.3, πυγμῇ νίψασθαι is interpr. diligently (v.l. πυκνά, often).

children.label: II
children.definition: the distance from the elbow to the knuckles, = 18 δάκτυλοι, Thphr. HP 9.11.5, Poll. 2.147, 158.
of or for boxing, An.Ox. 3.223.

definition: πυγμομαχία, ἡ, f.l. for πυγμαχία, EM 695.55.

children.definition: fire-tail, i.e. glow-worm, Lampyris noctiluca, Arist. HA 523b21 (v.l. πτερόποδες), 551b24 (v.l. πυρολαμπίδες); cf. πυριλαμπίς.
a πυγών long, Hp. Morb. 2.33, Thphr. HP 3.17.6 ( -γων- codd.), Menesth. ap. Ath. 11.494b.
short, stumpy root, Hsch.
with legs set far back, like the grebe or puffin, Hsch.

definition: πυγοστόλος, ον, epith. of a woman,

children.definition: decorating the πυγή, with collat. notion of lewd, Hes. Op. 373.

definition: πυγούσιος, α, ον, poet. for πυγονιαῖος,

children.definition: of the length of a πυγών, Od. 10.517, 11.25, Arat. 896.
the distance from the elbow to the first joint of the fingers, = 20 δάκτυλοι or 5 παλαισταί, Hdt. 2.175, X. Cyn. 10.2, Archestr. Fr. 29, Hero *Geom. 4.10.

dance the fling, ὄνον ἐπάραντα τὰ σκέλη πυδαρίζειν App.Prov. 4.25: hence ἀποπῡδᾰρίζειν μόθωνα kick up (i.e. dance) a μόθων, Ar. Eq. 697: διαπῡδᾰρίζει ( -πονδ- cod.), = διαναβάλλεται, διαναρρίπτεται, Com.Adesp. 977. (Falsely expld. as Aeol. for *ποδαρίζω (from πούς) or from *πυγαρίζω (from πυγή) by Irenaeus ap. EM 696.2 = Sch. Ar. l.c.): hence πῡδᾰρισμός, ὁ, = δυσχέρεια, Zonar.

definition: πυέλιον, τό, Dim. of πύελος: prov., ἀστραπὴ ἐκ πυελίου ‘when pigs begin to fly’, Diogenian. 3.7.
πυελίς, ίδος, ἡ, in a seal-ring,

children.definition: setting, socket of the stone, Ar. Fr. 315, Lys. Fr. 106S.
bearing or axle-box, Hero Aut. 5.3, Apollod. Poliorc. 148.8.
eye-socket, Ruf. Anat. 9 (sg.), Oss. 4 (pl.).
cup of the flowers of τιθύμαλλος, Dsc. 4.164.

children.label: II
children.definition: πυαλίς), sarcophagus, dat. πυαλίδι TAM 2(1).249 ( Lycia): acc. πυαλεῖδα IGRom. 4.1285 ( Thyatira): but πυελεῖδα TAM 2(1).342 ( Lycia).
πυαλίς), reservoir, basin, IG 4.823.9,43 ( Troezen).

definition: πύελος (so Phld. Mort. 33) or πύᾰλος, ἡ,

children.definition: trough, for feeding animals, Od. 19.553.
bathing-tub, Hp. Acut. 65, Ar. Eq. 1060, Pax 843, Th. 562, Crates Com. 15.5, Eup. 256, PEnteux. 83 (iii B.C.).
vat, kitchen-boiler, Ar. V. 141.

sarcophagus, Thphr. Lap. 6, Arr. An. 6.29.9, CIG 3785, al. ( Nicomedia), 4164 ( Sinope); πύαλος, ib. 2050 ( Philippopolis), 3777 ( Nicomedia), IGRom. 1.624 ( Tomi), Supp.Epigr. 4.106 ( Rome, ii A.D.).
infundibulum of the brain, Gal. 2.709, UP 8.3, 9.3.
Hermes 38.283. [ ῡ Od. l.c., perh. metri gr., ῠ Att.]
like a trough, hollow, Arist. HA 547b27.
curdled milk obtained from an animalʼs stomach, containing (and used as) rennet, Arist. HA 522b5, PA 676a6, GA 739b22, Nic. Al. 68, 323.

definition: πύη [ ῡ], ἡ, = φθίσις, prob. f.l. for φθόη in Aret. SD 1.8.
πυήρ: ἀναπεπλησμένον, Hsch.; πυηρόν: ἀναπεπλασμένον, Theognost. Can. 23.

children.definition: suppuration, ἢν ἐς π. τρέπηται Aret. CA 1.7.
of suppuration, δύναμις Gal. 10.887.

definition: Πυθαγόρας, ου, Ion. Πῡθᾰγόρ-ης, εω, ὁ, Pythagoras, Hdt. 4.95, etc.

children.definition: of P. or Pythagorean, Pl. R. 530d, Arist. Metaph. 985b23.
to be a disciple of Pythagoras, Antiph. 226.8, Alex. 220.1.

Arist. de An. 407b22; βαθύτης Hierocl. in CA 26p.480M.; τὰ Π., title of work by Zeno the Stoic, D.L. 7.4. Adv. -κῶς in the Pythagorean manner, Plu. QConv. 2.728e, Iamb. Comm.Math. 22: Comp. -κώτερον S.E. M. 4.11, Iamb. Protr. 21. ιή.
Pythagorean doctrines, Alex. 220.7 (pl.).

definition: Πυθαγοριστής, οῦ ( Dor. -ικτάς, ᾶ, Theoc. 14.5), ὁ,

children.definition: follower of Pythagoras, Antiph. 160; title of play by Aristopho, Ath. 4.161e: applied only to exoteric followers, acc. to Iamb. VP 18.80: fem. Πῡθᾰγορ-ίδες γυναῖκες ib. 36.267.
IG 12(1).820,834; also at Corinth, Sparta, etc., Paus. 2.35.2, 3.10.8, etc.: hence Πῡθᾱ-εῖα, and Πυθαῆα, τά, his festival at Sparta and Megara, IG 5(1).659, 7.48.
consult his oracle, Eust. 274.16.
τὸ ἱερὸν (at Chalcedon) τοῦ Ἀπόλλωνος τοῦ Π. SIG 550.4 ( Delph., iii B.C.), cf. St.Byz. s.v. Πυθώ; also ῥόος Π. IG 9(1).699.
sacred mission or θεωρία sent to Delphi, Is. 7.27, SIG 696 A 6 ( Delph., ii B.C.), prob. ib. 296 (iv B.C.).
SIG 696 B 19 (ii B.C.), Str. 9.2.11; also as Adj., Πυθᾰϊστὴς χορός Call. Iamb. 1.229 (fr 194.33 P).
one who plays the νόμος expressing the battle between Apollo and the Python, IG 5(1).758 ( Sparta), 7.1773.18 ( Thespiae), 14.737 ( Naples), Seneca Ep. 76.4, Diom. p.492 K.
putrefaction, Eratosth. 18 (pl.), Nic. Th. 466 (pl.).
Zonar.

definition: Πυθία (sc. ἱέρεια), Ion. Πυθίη Hdt. 1.13, al., Call. Iamb. 1.222: ἡ:—

children.definition: Pythia, priestess of Pythian Apollo at Delphi, who uttered the responses of the oracle, Hdt. l.c., etc.; cf. προφήτης.

children.label: II
children.definition: Πυθίη, epith. of Artemis at Branchidae, CIG 2866, 2885.

the Pythian games, celebrated at Delphi in honour of Pythian Apollo, ἐν Πυθίοισι νικᾶν Pi. N. 2.9; Π. ἀνελόμενος Hdt. 6.122; ἐνίκα τὰ Π. τῷ τεθρίππῳ D. 59.33: also of festivals elsewhere, IG 3.129, etc.
to be inspired by Apollo, prophesy, St.Byz. s.v. Πυθώ.
of the Pythian games, περίοδοι Gal. 7.476.

definition: Πυθιάς, άδος, pecul. fem. of Πύθιος, Π. βοά a song

children.definition: to Apollo, S. Fr. 490; νίκη Pl. Lg. 807c.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst.,
ἱέρεια), = Πυθία, the Pythian priestess, Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.295d; Π. προφῆτις, one of the dramatis personae in A. Eu.
ἑορτή), the celebration of the Pythian games, Pi. P. 1.32, 5.21, IG 14.747 ( Naples); ἁ Πυθιὰς ἁ ἱαρά, ἁ ἱερομηνία ἁ Πυθιάς, ib. 2(2).1126.38, 44.
νίκη), Pythian victory, ἐνίκησε . . Πυθιάδας ἕξ Paus. 6.14.10, cf. 10.7.4.
πομπή), sacred mission from Athens to Delphi, Ephor. 31 J., dub. in SIG 296 ( Delph., iv B.C.): leg. Πυθαΐς.
ὁδός), sacred way from Delphi to Tempe, Ael. VH 3.1.
Hsch. s.v. ἀστραπὴ διʼ Ἅρματος.

of or for Pytho, Pythian, χρηστήρια, ἑστία, A. Th. 747 (lyr.), E. Andr. 1067; μαντεῖον S. El. 32, Th. 2.17; ἆθλα S. El. 49; δάφνη Ar. Pl. 213; τὸ Π. (sc. χρηστήριον) Id. Eq. 220; Π. αὐλητής, κιθαριστής, IG 7.1776 ( Thespiae); νικήσαντα παίδων Πυθικῶν πάλην IGRom. 4.244 (Alexandria Troas), cf. 1064.7 ( Cos), Supp.Epigr. 3.335.7, al. ( Thespiae, ii A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Πυθικόν, τό, name of a work on tooth- and mouth-washes by Damocrates, Gal. 12.889.
temple of the Pythian Apollo at Athens, IG 1(2).188.64, Th. 2.15, Str. 9.2.11, Paus. 9.35.7; at Poeessa, IG 12(5).1100 (v/iv B.C.).

definition: Πυθιονίκης [ ῑ], ου, Dor. -ᾱς, α, ὁ,

children.definition: conqueror in the Pythian games, Pi. P. 9.1, Hdt. 8.47, PLond. 3.1178.67 (ii A.D.), Hld. 5.19:—fem. Πῡθιο-νίκη, ἡ, pr.n. of a ἑταίρα, afterwards deified as Π. Ἀφροδίτη, Python 1.8, Antiph. 26.20, Timocl. 17, Philem. 16, Theopomp.Hist. 244, 245, Paus. 1.37.2; called Πυθονίκη in D.S. 17.108, Plu. Phoc. 22 (so, of another woman, IG 3.3823).

children.label: II
children.definition: Πυθιονίκη = Pythian victory, Hld. 5.19.
of or belonging to a Pythian victory, Pi. P. 6.5, etc.

definition: Πύθιος [ ῡ; ῑ metri gr. in h.Ap. 373], α, ον, ( Πῡθώ)

children.definition: Pythian, i.e. Delphian, epith. of Apollo, l.c., Pi. O. 14.11, etc. ( Π. alone is f.l. in E. Ion 285); ἐν Πυθίου in his temple, Th. 6.54 (citing Πυθίου ἐν τεμένει from IG 1(2).761), IG 2(2).17.10, prob. in Pl. Grg. 472b; also οἱ Πύθιοι, αἱ Πύθιαι, the gods and goddesses worshipped at Pytho or Delphi, Ar. Th. 332, cf. IG 14.2436 ( Massilia).
Pi. P. 3.73, 10.26, I. 7(6).15; ἀκταί S. OC 1047 (lyr.); ἀστραπαί E. Ion 285; κύκνος Ar. Av. 870.

children.label: II
children.definition: οἱ Πύθιοι, at Sparta, four persons whose office it was to consult the Delphic oracle on affairs of state, Hdt. 6.57, X. Lac. 15.5, etc.; cf. Πυθία, Πύθια, Πύθιον.
to be a base of a series, prob. in Iamb. in Nic. p.117 P. ( -μένειν codd.).

basic, first in a series (cf. πυθμήν III), ὁ δύο ῥίζα τῆς π. τοῦ μείζονος σχέσεως Theol.Ar. 13; π. ὅροι Iamb. in Nic. p.49 P., al.; of the τριάς, Adam. Vent. 46: Comp., Nicom. Ar. 2.2: Sup., Theol.Ar. 11. Adv. -κῶς ib. 34.

data.quote: ὁ δύο ῥίζα τῆς π. τοῦ μείζονος σχέσεως

children.definition: Dim. of πυθμήν, BGU 781 ii 15 (i A.D.), Gp. 4.4, Hsch. s.v. πτερνίς.
from the foundation, π. οὐκ ἴσασιν not at all, Hp. Acut. 40, cf. Erot.

bottom, of a cup or jar, δειλὴ δʼ ἐνὶ πυθμένι φειδώ Hes. Op. 369 (so prov. ἐν τῷ πυθμένι τοῦ πίθου Lib. Ep. 127.2); τὼ δὲ πίθω πατάγεσκʼ ὀ πύθμην Alc. Supp. 25.9, cf. Arist. Pr. 936a32, Sor. 1.91; distd. from πύνδαξ, Arist. Pr. 938a14; φιάλη . . ἡ ἐπὶ τὸν π. καὶ τὸ στόμα τιθεμένη Asclep.Myrl. ap. Ath. 11.501d, cf. Apollod. ib. a; this sense is doubtful in Il. 11.635 (cf. infr. 4 and Ath. 11.488f), and in IG 1(2).282.111, 11(2).161 B 120, 287 B 89,131,143 ( Delos, iii B.C.); ἐν τῷ π. ἐπιγραφὴν ἔχουσα Inscr.Délos 313a102, cf. 320 B 45, al. (iii B.C.).

data.quote: τὼ δὲ πίθω πατάγεσκʼ ὀ πύθμην
φιάλη . . ἡ ἐπὶ τὸν π. καὶ τὸ στόμα τιθεμένη

children.definition: base, foundation, χθόνα ἐκ πυθμένων κραδαίνειν A. Pr. 1046 (anap.); π. γαίης, πέτρης, Orph. A. 92, L. 162; foot of a mountain, Arat. 989.
bottom, depth, π. θαλάσσης, πόντου, λίμνης, Hes. Th. 932, Sol. 13.20, Thgn. 1035; τοῦ πελάγους Pl. Phd. 109c, cf. 112b; also Ταρτάρου, abyss, Pi. Fr. 207.
support under a cupʼs handle, δύω δʼ ὑπὸ πυθμένες ἦσαν Il. 11.635 (cf. supr. I); legs of a tripod, 18.375.
sockets, ἐκ πυθμένων ἔκλινε κλῇθρα S. OT 1261.

fundus of univalves, Arist. HA 529a6, PA 680a23; lower parts of the testes, Ruf. Onom. 105 (but, upper part of the uterus, Sor. 1.7, Gal. 2.889); also γενειάδος π. A. Fr. 27; distal end of a quince, Aët. 1.111.

Δίκας ἐρείδεται π. the base of Justice is firmly set, A. Ch. 646 (lyr.); π. κακῶν Orph. A. 893; πυθμένες λόγων fundamental principles, Protag. ap. D.L. 9.54; Ζεὺς π. γαίης τε καὶ οὐρανοῦ Orph. Fr. 168.4.

data.quote: Ζεὺς π. γαίης τε καὶ οὐρανοῦ

children.label: II
children.definition: stock, root of a tree, παρὰ πυθμένʼ ἐλαίης Od. 13.122, 372, cf. 23.204; ἐν π. φηγοῦ Hes. Fr. 134.8; π. δρυός Ion Trag. 28; ὁ π. τῆς ῥίζης Dsc. 4.104, cf. 3.126; σεύτλου πυθμένες beet- roots, BGU 1118.17 (i B.C.); ἁλικακκάβων π. ib. 1120.37 (i B.C.); ἀμπέλου Str. 2.1.14, cf. PPetr. 1p.78 (iii B.C.); ἐπὶ τοῦ αὐτοῦ π. Thphr. HP 2.2.9, cf. CP 3.13.3: metaph., ἐκ νεάτου π. ἐς κορυφήν Sol. 13.10.
stem, stalk, πυροῦ, κριθῶν, Arist. GA 728b36, D.S. 1.14; σύκων Poll. 2.170; τυτθὸν . . ἐν χθονὶ πυθμένα τείνει Nic. Th. 639.

children.label: b
children.definition: stem, stock of a family, A. Ch. 260, Supp. 106 (lyr.); σμικροῦ γένοιτʼ ἂν σπέρματος μέγας π., i.e. great things might come from small, Id. Ch. 204; πυθμένες θάλλουσιν ἐσθλῶν B. 5.198; π. δικῶν, of a litigious person, Com.Adesp. 896.

children.label: III
children.definition: base of a series, i.e. lowest number possessing a given property, π. ὁ δέκα (of the numbers such that the previous integers contain an equal number of primes and non-primes) Speus. ap. Theol.Ar. 62; ἐπίτριτος π. the first couple of numbers giving the ratio 4:3, Pl. R. 546c, cf. Nicom. Ar. 1.21, 2.19. [ ῠ in A. ll. cc.; ῡ by position in Ep., etc.] (Cf. Skt. budhnás ‘bottom, base’, Lat. fundus, OE. botm.)
from Pytho or Delphi, St.Byz.
at Pytho or Delphi, Pi. O. 7.10, P. 11.49, Simon. 153, E. Fr. 923, Ar. Lys. 1131, Th. 5.18, Pl. Ly. 205c, etc.
to Pytho or Delphi, Πυθοῖ καὶ Ὀλυμπίαζε Plu. Demetr. 11.—The trisyll. form Πυθόϊ is cited by Choerob. in Theod. 1.310 H. from Pi., cf. I. 7(6).51.
Hes. Sc. 480, Aristocl. ap. Eus. PE 14.18.

definition: Πυθοῖος, ὁ (sc. μήν), name of month at Halos, IG 9(2).109a13.

children.definition: confirmed by the Pythian god: τὰ Π. the Pythian oracles, A. Ag. 1255.
slaying the serpent Python, Orph. H. 34.4.
dragon-slayer, epith. of Apollo, PMag.Lond. 47.32.
seized with Pythian frenzy, Hsch., Phot.
the Pythian prophet, Π. Λοξίας A. Ch. 1030.

children.label: II
children.definition: Π. ἑστία the prophetic seat at Pytho, S. OT 965.
sent by the Pythian oracle, φυγάς A. Ch. 940 (lyr., sed leg. -τος).
delivered by the Pythian god, μαντεύματα A. Ch. 901; νόμοι X. Lac. 8.5; Πυθόχρηστον ἔσχον c. inf., Phld. Mus. p.85K.; μαντεῖον Arist. Pol. 1331a27; κατὰ Πυθόχρηστον Arg. S. OC

children.label: II
children.definition: declared or appointed by the Pythian oracle, ὁ Π. Λοξίου νεανίας E. Ion 1218; ἀποικίας ἡγεμών Plu. Symp. 2.163b; ἐξηγητής SIG 697 E 9 ( Delph., ii B.C.), IG 3.241, Tim. Lex. s.v. ἐξηγηταί; θυσία Clitodem. 14.
SIG 1014.74,160; of Dionysus, ib. 145; of Kore, ib. 90 ( Erythrae, iii B.C.).

definition: πύθω [ῡ], Ep. impf. πύθεσκον A.R. 4.1530: fut. πύσω Il. 4.174: aor. ἔπῡσα ( κατ-) h.Ap. 371, Ep. πῦσα ib. 374 (but πύσε [ῠ] Call. Fr. 313): — Pass., only used in pres. and impf.:—

children.definition: cause to rot, σέο δʼ ὀστέα πύσει ἄρουρα Il. 4.174; σέ γʼ αὐτοῦ πύσει γαῖα h.Ap. 369; αὐτοῦ πῦσε πέλωρ μένος Ἠελίοιο ib. 374, cf. Hes. Op. 626:— Pass., become rotten, decay, moulder, ὁ δέ θʼ αἵματι γαῖαν ἐρεύθων πύθεται Il. 11.395; ὀστέα π. ὄμβρῳ Od. 1.161, cf. Hes. Sc. 153; ὀστεόφιν θὶς ἀνδρῶν πυθομένων Od. 12.46; πυθομένοισιν ἐφʼ ἕλκεσι A.R. 4.1405; ἐπύθετό μοι ὁ ὀφθαλμός PSI 4.299.5 (iii A.D.). (Cf. Skt. pu᷄yati ‘putrefy’, Lat. pūs, etc.)

data.quote: ὁ δέ θʼ αἵματι γαῖαν ἐρεύθων πύθεται

definition: Πυθώ, gen. οῦς, dat. οῖ, ἡ,

children.definition: Pytho, the region in which lay the city of Delphi, Πυθοῖ ἔνι πετρηέσσῃ Il. 9.405; Π. ἐν ἠγαθέῃ Od. 8.80, Hes. Th. 499, etc.; of Delphi itself, Pi. P. 4.66, 10.4, Hdt. 1.54, etc. (Acc. to the legend, derived from the rotting of the serpent, h.Ap. 372.)

definition: Πυθώδε (better Πυθὼ δέ, cf. A.D. Pron. 87.30), Adv., ( Πυθώ)

children.definition: to Pytho, Od. 11.581, S. OT 603, 788, Ar. Av. 189, SIG 56.9 ( Argos, v B.C.), Pl. Lg. 950e.
from Pytho, Pi. I. 1.65, St.Byz.
Python, slain by Apollo, Ephor. 31 (b) J., Apollod. 1.4.1, Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.293c.

children.label: II
children.definition: παιδίσκη ἔχουσα πνεῦμα Πύθωνα a spirit of divination, Act. Ap. 16.16.
Πύθωνες, ventriloquists, Plu. Def.orac. 2.414e, cf. Hsch.

definition: Πυθών, ῶνος, ἡ, = Πυθώ, Il. 2.519, h.Merc. 178, Simon. 125, Pi. O. 6.48, S. OT 152 (lyr.), Ar. Ra. 659, al.

children.definition: ὑοσκύαμος, Ps.- Dsc. 4.68; = dracontea, symphoniaca, Gloss.

definition: πύϊον τὸ γάλα, Hsch.; cf. πυός.

πυκάζω, Od. 12.225, Dor. πυκάσδω Theoc. 3.14: impf. ἐπύκαζον Id. 20.22: Ep. aor. inf. πυκάσαι Od. 11.320; part. πυκάσσας Hes. Op. 542; ind. ἐπύκασσα Sapph. 89:— Med., Cratin. 98.7, etc.: Ep. fut. πυκάσσομαι Max. 513: aor. subj. πυκάσωμαι AP 11.19 ( Strat.):— Pass., aor. ἐπυκάσθην Hdt. 7.197, etc.: pf. πεπύκασμαι Od. 22.488, Hes. Op. 793; Aeol. part. πεπυκάδμενος Sapph. 56: ( πύκα):—

children.definition: Hdt., v. supr., and later Prose, D.S. 5.13), cover closely, freq. with collat. notion of protection, νεφέλῃ πυκάσασα ἓ αὐτήν Il. 17.551; πύκασεν κάρη ἀμφιτεθεῖσα [ἡ κυνέη] 10.271; νῆα π. λίθοισι surround a ship with stones, so as to protect it while lying up, Hes. Op. 624: generally, cover thickly, of a youthʼs chin, π. γένυς εὐανθέϊ λάχνῃ Od. 11.320; πέδιλα πίλοις ἔντοσθε π. lining them with thick felt, Hes. Op. 542; π. στεφάνοις cover thick with crowns, Orac. ap. D. 21.52, Theoc. 2.153, cf. IG 3.758: —also Med., μελιλώτῳ κάρα πυκάζομαι Cratin. l.c.; στεφάνοις κεφαλὰς πυκασώμεθα AP l.c.: without στεφάνοις, crown, deck with garlands, πύκαζε κρᾶτʼ ἐμὸν νικηφόρον E. Tr. 353:—also Med., λουσάμενοι . . πυκασώμεθα let us put on crowns, AP 5.11 ( Rufin.):— Pass., στέμμασι πᾶς πυκασθείς Hdt. l.c., cf. E. Alc. 796; δάφνῃ πυκασθείς (v.l. σκιασθείς) Id. Andr. 1115; βωμὸς ἄνθεσι πεπύκασται Xenoph. 1.11; ὄρεξιν ἥβης (cf. ἥβη I.4) πυκαζομένης Ps.-Democr.in Hp. Ep. 23 (s. v.l.):— Pass. is used by Hom. only in pf. part. πεπυκασμένος thickly covered, ὄζοισιν Il. 14.289; ἅρματα δὲ χρυσῷ πεπυκασμένα κασσιτέρῳ τε 23.503; but ἅρματα εὖ πεπ. well covered over (i. e. stowed away), 2.777; ῥάκεσιν πεπυκασμένος ὤμους Od. 22.488, cf. E. Rh. 713 (lyr.); ὄρος πεπυκασμένον a hill well-clothed with wood, Hes. Th. 484; χώρα πεπυκασμένη δρυμοῖς D.S. l.c.; Aeol. πεπυκάδμενος, covered, hidden, Sapph. 56:— Med., κόσμῳ πυκάζου τῷδε cover thyself, E. Heracl. 725; π. τεύχεσιν δέμας Id. Rh. 90 (v.l. -αζε).

data.quote: ἅρματα δὲ χρυσῷ πεπυκασμένα κασσιτέρῳ τε

children.definition: Ἕκτορα δʼ αἰνὸν ἄχος πύκασε φρένας threw a shadow over his soul, Il. 8.124, 17.83:— Pass., παρθενίης αἰδοῖ πεπυκασμένος Epigr.Gr. 875.2 ( Sinope); also νόον πεπυκασμένος close, cautious of mind, Hes. Op. 793.

children.label: II
children.definition: close, shut up, ἐντὸς πυκάζοιεν σφέας αὐτούς shelter themselves closely within, Od. 12.225; πύκαζε θᾶσσον (sc. τὸ δῶμα) shut it close, S. Aj. 581.
that which is close, covered, or thick, Sm. Ps. 117(118).27.
of close or cautious mind, shrewd, Od. 1.438: also written parox. πυκιμήδης, h.Cer. 153, Q.S. 7.189.

definition: πυκινά, neut. pl. used as Adv.,
πυκινόθριξ, τρῐχος, ὁ, ἡ, = πυκνόθριξ, Nonn. D. 7.322, al.

children.definition: moving frequently, Hp. Art. 14.

definition: πυκινόφρων, ὁ, ἡ, gen. ονος, = πυκιμηδής, βουλή, ῥήτρη, h.Merc. 538, AP 11.350 ( Agath.); of a person, Hes. Fr. 143, Q.S. 5.98.

children.definition: to be frequent, EM 442.21, Gloss.
oft-times, Arist. Pr. 872a22, 874a9.
close-fitted, Democr. ap. Placit. 3.3.11.
assembled in the Pnyx, δῆμος π. Ar. Eq. 42: fem. πυκν-ῖτις, from the Pnyx, [ κονία] IG 2(2).1672.199.
covered with buds, Thphr. CP 3.7.11.
with frequent knots or joints, Dsc. 1.18, al.
with teeth close together, Sch. Opp. H. 1.170.
thick-haired, Nonn. D. 36.302 (leg. πυκιν-).
thick with fruit, Luc. Am. 12.
ever in dangers, v.l. for μικροκίνδυνος in Arist. EN 1124b7.
Ruf. ap. Orib. 7.26.37 (v.l. -κολον: -κομον cj. Daremberg).
motherwort, Leonurus Cardiaca, Dsc. 4.174, Plin. HN 26.57; cf. foreg.
to be riddled with holes, of a shield, S. Fr. 35.

definition: πυκνόν, neut. Adj. used as Adv.,

children.definition: covered with thick clouds, Sch. Arat. 412.
sail constantly, f.l. for νυκτοπλοέω, Hipparch. 1.7.1.
having rapid respiration, Hp. Epid. 6.4.4.
rapid respiration, Gal. 17(2).128.
make thick, Eust. 1546. 44.
with close or narrow pores, Alex.Aphr. Pr. 2.76.
many and feathered, ἀηδόνες S. OC 17.
thick with berries, AP 6.22 ( Zon., ap. Suid., but πυκνόρρωγα or πυκνορρῶγα codd. as in Str. 15.2.14).
with matted roots, Thphr. HP 3.11.4, al., Dsc. 1.1.

definition: πυκνός, ή, όν, poet. also πῠκῐνός, ή, όν, both forms in Ep. (v. infr.) and Lyr., Pi. O. 13.52 ( Sup.), B. Fr. 1; Aeol. πύκνος Sapph. 1.11, Alc. Supp. 14.9 ( πύκινος is dub. l. Id. 82); Trag. πυκνός, exc. S. in lyr., Aj. 1208, Ph. 854; πυκινός once in Com., Eub. 38 (s.v.l.): Lacon. Sup. πουκότατος is corrupt in Simm. 26.17:—

children.definition: close, compact.

children.label: I
children.definition: close, firm, solid, πυκινὸς θώρηξ Il. 15.529; χλαῖναν πυκνὴν καὶ μεγάλην Od. 14.521; πυκινὸν νέφος Il. 5.751; πυκινὸν λέχος well-stuffed, firm bed, 9.621, Od. 7.340; πυκνὸν καὶ μαλακόν Il. 14.349; Ἁρμονίης πυκινῷ κρυφῷ Emp. 27.3; σπάρτα πυκνὰ ἐστραμμένα X. An. 4.7.15; π. δέμας Parm. 8.59; of a sponge, Hp. Ulc. 2; π. ὀστοῦν Pl. Ti. 75b, cf. Hp. VM 22; [ σάρκες] Pl. Ti. 74e; χρυσοῦ πυκνότερον ib. 59b; ἔβενος Thphr. HP 1.5.5; πλεύμων Plu. QConv. 2.698b; χωρία ib. 650d; πυκινὴν νάπαις Ἄζιλιν Call. Ap. 89; [ ὁ ἐλαιὼν] πυκνός ἐστι τοῖς φυτοῖς overgrown with plants, PFay. 113.8 (i/ii A.D.); ξοῒς χαρακτὴ π. IG 7.3073.104 ( Lebad., ii B.C.); of a woman, thick-set, stocky, Sor. 1.34.
narrow, constricted, οὐ διέρχεται . . ἀρκέουσα ἰκμάς . ., πυκνῆς τῆς ὁδοῦ ἐούσης Hp. Mul. 1.73; πυκνοὺς ἔχουσι τοὺς πόρους τοῦ σώματος Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.6.

data.quote: οὐ διέρχεται . . ἀρκέουσα ἰκμάς . ., πυκνῆς τῆς ὁδοῦ ἐούσης
πυκνοὺς ἔχουσι τοὺς πόρους τοῦ σώματος

children.label: II
children.definition: close-packed, crowded, πυκιναὶ κίνυντο φάλαγγες Il. 4.281; τῶν δὲ στίχες ἥατο πυκναί 7.61, etc.; πυκινὸν λόχον εἷσαν 4.392, etc.(v. infr. III.1); πυκνὰ καρήατα λαῶν 11.309; πυκνοὶ ἐφέστασαν ἀλλήλοισιν 13.133, cf. Od. 5.480; σταυροῖσιν πυκινοῖσι Il. 24.453; σταυροὺς . . πυκνοὺς καὶ θαμέας Od. 14.12; of thick plumage, πυκινὰ πτερά 5.53; πτερὰ πυκνά Il. 11.454, 23.879; but πύκνα πτέρα fast-beating wings, Sapph. 1.11 (and so perh. Hom. ll. cc.); freq. of thick foliage, ὕλη, λόχμη, θάμνοι, ὄζοι, ῥωπήϊα, δρυμά, πέταλα, Il. 18.320, Od. 19.439, 5.471, Il. 21.245, Od. 14.473, 10.150, 19.520; π. νέφεα Hes. Op. 553; πυκινοῖσι λίθοισι with close-laid stones, Il. 16.212; πυκινοῖσι . . βελέεσσι with a thick shower of darts, 11.576; πυκνῆσιν λιθάδεσσιν Od. 14.36; τοξεύματα πολλὰ καὶ π. Hdt. 7.218; πυκνοῖς ὄσσοις δεδορκώς, of Argus, A. Pr. 678; πεπλεκτανημέναι π. δράκουσιν, of the Furies, Id. Ch. 1050; of thick-falling rain, snow, etc., πυκνῆς ἀκοῦσαι ψακάδος S. Fr. 636; πυκιναῖς δρόσοις Id. Aj. 1208 (lyr.); πυκνῇ νιφάδι E. Andr. 1129; π. ῥόος a dense current, Emp. 100.14; π. θρίξ X. Cyn. 4.6; π. τρίχες Pl. Prt. 321a; [ δένδρεα] Hdt. 4.22, cf. X. An. 4.8.2; τὰ μὲν π . . . τὰ δὲ μανὰ κατὰ τὴν φυτείαν Thphr. HP 1.8.2.

data.quote: τὰ μὲν π . . . τὰ δὲ μανὰ κατὰ τὴν φυτείαν

children.label: b
children.definition: in close order, opp. ἀραιός, Ascl. Tact. 4.1 ( Sup.), Arr. Tact. 11.1 ( Comp.).

frequent, numerous, πυκνοὺς θεοπρόπους ἴαλλε A. Pr. 658; τῶν π. φιλημάτων Id. Fr. 135; ὀδύναι πυκνόταται Hp. VM 22; πυκινῶν κρεγμῶν ἀκροαζομένα Epich. 109 (anap.); π. ὁδοὺς ἐλθόντα E. Tr. 235; π. βαίνων ἤλυσιν, of a blind man, Id. Ph. 844; ἐν πυκνῷ θεοῦ τροχῷ κυκλεῖται on the oft-revolving wheel, S. Fr. 871.1; μεταβολαὶ πυκνόταται Hp. Aër. 13; πνεῦμα πυκνότερον quicker breathing, Id. Acut. 16; π. σφυγμὸς ἢ μανός Plu. Sanit. 2.136f; continuous, constant, φῶς Corp.Herm. 16.10; ἐρωτήμασι πυκνοῖς χρώμενοι Th. 7.44; ἡ . . εἰωθυῖά μοι μαντικὴ . . πάνυ πυκνὴ ἦν Pl. Ap. 40a; ἐπιθυμίαι π. τε καὶ σφοδραί Id. R. 573e; τὰς ἐντεύξεις π. ποιεῖσθαι Isoc. 1.20: c. inf., πυκνοτέραν εἰσαφικνεῖσθαι πᾶσιν ἀνθρώποις ποιεῖν τὴν πόλιν more frequently visited by . ., X. Vect. 5.1 codd.

data.quote: ἡ . . εἰωθυῖά μοι μαντικὴ . . πάνυ πυκνὴ ἦν

children.label: III
children.definition: well put together, compact, strong, πυκινὸς δόμος, χηλός, θύραι, θάλαμος, κευθμῶνες (v. infr. B. III.1), Il. 10.267, Od. 13.68, Il. 14.167, Od. 23.229, 10.283; ἀσπὶς ῥινοῖσιν πυκινή Il. 13.804; π. δῶμα Xenoph. 17: hence, close, concealed, πυκινὸς δόλος Il. 6.187; and so perhaps π. λόχος, v. supr. II.1.

πυκνόν, τό, part of the tetrachord in which the intervals are small, defined as τὸ ἐκ δύο διαστημάτων συνεστηκὸς ἃ συντεθέντα ἔλαττον διάστημα περιέξει τοῦ λειπομένου διαστήματος ἐν τῷ διὰ τεσσάρων Aristox. Harm. p.24M., cf. Plu. Mus. 2.1135b, etc.

data.quote: τὸ ἐκ δύο διαστημάτων συνεστηκὸς ἃ συντεθέντα ἔλαττον διάστημα περιέξει τοῦ λειπομένου διαστήματος ἐν τῷ διὰ τεσσάρων

children.label: IV
children.definition: strong of its kind, sore, excessive, ἄτη Il. 24.480; μελεδῶναι Od. 19.516; ἄχος Il. 16.599.

children.label: V
children.definition: shrewd, wise, πυκιναὶ φρένες 14.294, cf. Alc. Supp. 14.9, B. l.c.; νόος Il. 15.461; μήδεα 3.208; βουλή 2.55; ἐφετμή 18.216; μῦθοι Od. 3.23; ἔπος Il. 11.788; θυμός, βουλαί, Pi. P. 4.73, I. 7(6).8; φρήν E. IA 67; μήτιδι πυκνῇ Orac. ap. Hdt. 7.141, cf. IG 3.1320: in Prose, πυκνὴ διάνοια Pl. R. 568a; τὸ π. terseness of expression, D.H. Th. 24.

sagacious, shrewd, crafty, cunning, Σίσυφος πυκνότατος παλάμαις Pi. O. 13.52; κύων πυκινώτατον ἑρπετόν Id. Fr. 106; πυκινοί the wise, S. Ph. 854 (lyr.); πυκνότατον κίναδος Ar. Av. 430 (lyr.); πυκνός τις καὶ σοφὸς γνώμην ἀνήρ Critias 25.12.

data.quote: πυκνός τις καὶ σοφὸς γνώμην ἀνήρ

children.label: B
children.definition: Adv. πυκινῶς, and after Hom. πυκνῶς, θύραι or σανίδες πυκινῶς ἀραρυῖαι close or fast shut, Il. 9.475, Od. 2.344, etc.
sorely (v. supr. A. IV), πυκινῶς ἀκαχήμενος Il. 19.312, cf. Od. 19.95, al.; constantly, ὅταν π. διᾴττωσι X. Cyn. 6.22.
sagaciously, shrewdly, π. ὑποθήσομαι Od. 1.279, cf. Il. 21.293; πυκνῶς ἀνευρεῖν Ar. Th. 438 (lyr., s.v.l.).

children.label: II
children.definition: πυκνόν, πυκνά, πυκινόν, πυκινά as Adv., esp. in the sense much, often, πήρην πυκνὰ ῥωγαλέην a much torn wallet, a wallet full of holes, Od. 13.438, 17.198; πυκινόν περ ἀχεύων 11.88; τέττιξ . . καταχεύετʼ ἀοιδὴν πυκνόν Hes. Op. 584: in Prose, πυκνὰ ἐκπίπτει ὦμος Hp. Art. 2; πυκνὰ ἀποβλέπειν Pl. R. 501b; πυκνὰ στρέφεσθαι X. An. 6.1.8; πυκνὸν ἀναπνεῖν Arist. Rh. 1357b19; πυκνότερον ἰέναι, παρέρχεσθαι, Pl. R. 328d, D. 41.24; πυκνότερα ἐπάγειν Pl. Cra. 420d. Adv. -οτέρως Lesb.Gramm. 23, PLond. 5.1929 (iv A.D.): Sup. πυκνότατα X. Eq. 11.11.
πυκινὰ φρονεῖν (v. supr. A.V) Od. 9.445.

children.label: III
children.definition: Adv. πύκα [ ⏑⏑], thickly, solidly, θαλάμου πύκα ποιητοῖο 1.436; π. π. δόμοιο 22.455; σάκεος π. π. Il. 18.608; Λυκίων π. θωρηκτάων 12.317, cf. 15.689, 739; πύλαι π. στιβαρῶς ἀραρυῖαι 12.454.
θάλαμος πύκʼ ἐβάλλετο with thick-falling darts, 9.588.
wisely, π. φρονεῖν ib. 554, 14.217, Q.S. 1.449, al.; τρέφειν rear carefully, Il. 5.70.
with solid flesh, Hp. Vict. 3.78, Mul. 1.73, al., Arist. Pr. 861b29.
sow thick, Thphr. HP 8.6.2:— Pass., κύαμοι πυκνοσπορούμενοι ib. 8.7.2, cf. CP 4.14.2.
thick-sown, Thphr. CP 3.21.5.
thick-spotted, dappled, ἔλαφοι S. OC 1092 (lyr.).
with the pillars close together, i.e. at a distance of 1 1/2 diameters, opp. ἀραιόστυλος, Vitr. 3.3.1.
of a constricted habit of body, BKT 3p.20.
frequent pulse, Marcellin. Puls. 260.

closeness, thickness, denseness, solidity, [ νεφελῶν] Ar. Nu. 384, 406; [ χρυσοῦ] Pl. Ti. 59b; π. ἡ κάτω Epicur. Nat. 11.10; π. νοητή Phld. D. 3.11; of flesh, opp. μανότης, Hp. VM 22, Arist. EN 1129a23, etc.; opp. ἀραιότης, Id. Ph. 260b10 (pl.); ἡ π. τῆς ξυγκλῄσεως Th. 5.71.
π. κοιλίης costiveness, Hp. Epid. 6.3.1.
closer spacing of notes in music, opp. μανότης, Pl. Lg. 812d.
close formation of the phalanx, Arr. Tact. 11.1, 12.11; ἡ συνέχεια καὶ π. τῶν Ῥωμαίων Plu. Crass. 24.

data.quote: ἡ συνέχεια καὶ π. τῶν Ῥωμαίων

children.label: II
children.definition: frequency, μεταβολῶν Isoc. 4.116; μέγεθος καὶ πλῆθος καὶ πυκνότητες [λυπῶν] Pl. Lg. 734a; ἡ π. τῶν ἐννοιῶν Hermog. Id. 2.10 (pl.), Longin. ap. Porph. Plot. 19, cf. Arist. SE 175b34.

children.label: III
children.definition: sagacity, shrewdness, π. ἔνεστʼ ἐν τῷ τρόπῳ Ar. Eq. 1132 (lyr.); πιθανότης καὶ π. τοῦ ἀνδρός Plu. TG 15.
with thick-set eyes, π. κόραι E. Fr. 1063.14.

children.label: II
children.definition: with too many leaf-buds, Thphr. CP 3.15.3: Comp., Id. HP 5.4.1.
with thick foliage, Arist. Pr. 927a3 ( Comp.).

make close or solid, τὴν σάρκα Arist. Pr. 865b18, cf. Phld. Mort. 8; of winds, νέφεσι π. τὸν οὐρανόν thickens it, Arist. Mete. 364b24:— Pass., of vapour and air, ib. 342a21, 344b4; νεφῶν πυκνουμένων Epicur. Nat. 14 Fr. 6.

contract, condense, opp. μανόω, Arist. Spir. 485a31; of the effect of cold, Id. GA 783b1:— Pass., of frozen water, Antipho Soph. 29, Arist. Metaph. 1042b28, Mu. 394a33; ὁ σίδηρος ὑπὸ τοῦ ψυχροῦ πυκνοῦται is contracted, Plu. Alc. 6; of steam, ὁ ἀτμὸς -οῦται καὶ σταγόνες ἀποπίπτουσι Hp. Flat. 8.

children.label: II
children.definition: pack close, ἑωυτούς close their ranks, Hdt. 9.18, cf. Ascl. Tact. 10.4, Ael. Tact. 11.2 ( Pass.); τὸ βάθος ἐπὶ τὸ δεξιόν Plb. 18.24.8; τὴν τάξιν εἰς βάθος Plu. Flam. 8; σαυτὸν στρόβει πυκνώσας spin yourself round and concentrate your thoughts, Ar. Nu. 701 (lyr.):— Pass., to be compressed, εἰς ἐλάττω τόπον Arist. Cael. 296a18; [ τὴν διάνοιαν] πυκνοῦσθαι εἰκός Plu. QConv. 2.715c; τῷ πνεύματι πυκνουμένῳ, i.e. without taking breath, Id. Dem. 11.

children.label: b
children.definition: πυκνοῦται τὸ μέσον is compressed, becomes closer in signification, Arist. APo. 84b35; also πεπύκνωται [ὁ Λυσίας] τοῖς νοήμασι, of a terse style, D.H. Lys. 5.

children.label: III
children.definition: close, shut up, π. τοὺς πόρους Thphr. Sud. 27; τὸν στόμαχον Plu. QConv. 2.687d; φλέβες πυκνωθεῖσαι Hp. Salubr. 7.

children.label: IV
children.definition: Pass., to be thickly covered, ἡ γῆ τῶν [ἰχνῶν] πυκνοῦται with traces, X. Cyn. 5.7.

children.label: V
children.definition: become dense, Arist. Mete. 344a30, Pr. 934b15: in Tactics, πεπυκνωκότες ἀπὸ τῶν κεράτων ἐπὶ τὰ μέσα Plb. 3.115.6, cf. Ascl. Tact. 4.4, Ael. Tact. 11.6.

data.quote: πεπυκνωκότες ἀπὸ τῶν κεράτων ἐπὶ τὰ μέσα

children.definition: thick cloth, A. Supp. 235 (nisi leg. ἀμπυκώμασι).

children.label: II
children.definition: dense mass, concentration, Epicur. Ep. 1p.4U., al.; crowded detail, π. στερέμνιον Phld. D. 3.11; compression, Sor. 2.41; close order, τὸ π. τῶν πολεμίων J. BJ 6.1.3; τῶν σαρισῶν Plu. Aem. 20, cf. Phil. 9.
close planting or growth, τῶν κυάμων Str. 17.1.15; τῶν δένδρων, τῶν ὄζων, Alciphr. 3.37, 55; τῶν τριχῶν ib. 66, etc.
πυκνόν (v. πυκνός III.2), Pl. R. 531a.

condensation, opp. μάνωσις, Arist. Ph. 260b8; opp. ἀραίωσις, Epicur. Nat. 14 Fr. 11, Plu. QConv. 2.695b; π. ὑδατώδης, of the air, Arist. Mete. 372b31; τὸ νέφος π. ἀέρος Id. Top. 146b29; ἡ διὰ ψῦχος π. S.E. P. 1.238.

children.label: II
children.definition: πυκνόομαι) condensed matter, Arist. Mete. 344a16, Plu. QConv. 2.721a (pl.).
frequency of the pulse, Marcellin. Puls. 228.

children.label: III
children.definition: close order, κατὰ τὰς ἐναγωνίους π. Plb. 18.29.2; τῶν σαρισῶν Id. 18.30.3, cf. Onos. 10.2 (pl.); esp. of the phalanx, Ascl. Tact. 4.1,3, Ael. Tact. 11.3, Arr. Tact. 11.3.

children.label: IV
children.definition: aggregation, τῶν ἐκλελεγμένων Longin. 10.1.
serving to close the pores, δύναμις π. τῶν σωμάτων Dsc. 3.22, cf. Sor. 1.50, Aret. CA 2.1; ψυχροί τε καὶ π., of N. winds, bracing, Ptol. Tetr. 30.
boxing-ring, Suid.

children.label: II
children.definition: *πυκτός = πτυκτός) book-case, Zonar.
boxing, Gloss.
boxer, Gloss.

box, spar, X. Lac. 4.6, D. 4.40; οὕτω πυκτεύω ὡς οὐκ ἀέρα δέρων 1 Ep.Cor. 9.26; π. καὶ παγκρατιάζειν Pl. Grg. 456d; περὶ τεοῦς Ἑρμᾶς ποτʼ Ἄρευα π. Corinn. 11; ἐς σὸν κρᾶτα π. strike with the fist on the head, E. Cyc. 229: generally, fight, ξιφήρη π. Hld. 10.31; of gladiators, Rev.Arch. 30(1929).24 ( Gortyn):— Med., πεπύκτευται αὐτόν Philostr. Im. 2.19.

data.quote: οὕτω πυκτεύω ὡς οὐκ ἀέρα δέρων
περὶ τεοῦς Ἑρμᾶς ποτʼ Ἄρευα π.

children.definition: tablets, diptych, Cod.Just. 4.21.16 Intr., Just. Edict. 13.15.

children.label: II
children.definition: codex, Cod.Just. 4.21.22.10.

boxer, Xenoph. 2.15, Pi. O. 10(11).16, S. Tr. 442, Pl. Grg. 460d; opp. παλαιστής, Id. Lg. 819b; freq. in Inscrr., IG 1(2).846.7, 22.2311.32,47, 3.128.4, 743.14, etc., and Papyri, PLond. 3.1158.6 (iii A.D.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Plu. QConv. 2.724c.
fold, Suid.

skilled in boxing, Pl. Grg. 456d, Alc. 2.145d, etc.; opp. παλαιστικός, Arist. Rh. 1361b25: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) the art of boxing, Pl. Grg. 460d, Alc. 2.145d; π. ἐπιστήμη Arist. Cat. 10b3. Adv. -κῶς Sch. Theoc. 22.67: Comp. -ώτερον Philostr. Gym. 35.
of or for boxers, μάχη Pl. R. 333e; πόνοι, γυμνάσιον, Ruf. Sat.Gon. 34, Gal. 19.690; ἡ -κή plaster for boxers, Id. 13.509.
skill in boxing, Simp. in Cat. 214.18.
tablet, Sch. Ar. Pl. 39, Suid.; = βιβλίον, Zonar.; parox. acc. to Sch.D.T. p.195 H.

definition: πυκτίς (A), ίδος, ἡ, as if πτυκτίς,

children.definition: picture, AP 9.346 ( Leon.Alex.).

children.label: II
children.definition: parchment codex, Gal. 12.423.
badger, v.l. in Ar. Ach. 879 (sed leg. πικτίδας).
πυκτεύω, Suid. s.v. παγκρατιασταῖς.
the art of boxing, Xenoph. 2.4.

delegate sent to the Amphictyonic Council at Pylae, ἥκειν . . φασι τοὺς Πυλαγόρας Ar. Fr. 322:—also Πυλᾱγόρος or Πυλάγορος, Hdt. 7.214, D. 18.149 (v.l. -γόρας), Decr. Amphict. ib. 154, Aeschin. 3.113, 114 (v.l. -γόρας), 122, al., Str. 9.3.7 (both forms);

children.label: II
children.definition: διὰ βίου SIG 795 B 5 ( Delph., i A.D.); cf. Πυληγόρος.
to be a Πυλαγόρας, D. 18.155, Aeschin. 3.126.

definition: Πυλαία, Ion. Πυλ-αίη (sc. σύνοδος), ἡ, fem. of πυλαῖος,

children.definition: meeting of the Amphictyons at Pylae, Hdt. 7.213, Thphr. HP 9.10.2, etc.; π. ἠρινά SIG 230.27 ( Delph., iv B.C.); ἐαρινή Decr.Amphict. ap. D. 18.154; ὀπωρινά SIG 239 C 32 ( Delph., iv B.C.); μετοπωρινή Str. 9.3.7.
right of sending deputies to the Amphictyonic Council, D. 5.23, 6.22.
place where the Amphictyons met, GDI 2507.5, 2524.11 ( Delph., iii B.C.), Plu. Pyth. 2.409a.

children.label: II
children.definition: promiscuous crowd, such as was found at these meetings: hence μύθων ἀπιθάνων . . πυλαία farrago, Id. Art. 1, cf. 2.924d.

children.label: III
children.definition: St.Byz.) considered undesirable for Spartan youths, Id. 2.239c.
buffoons, mountebanks, such as flocked to Pylae and Delphi during the Amphictyonic assembly, Phot., Suid.

children.label: II
children.definition: liars (Rhod.), Hsch.
silly, ὀχλαγωγία Plu. Pyrrh. 29.
fighting at the gate, prob. in Stesich. 48 ( -λαμ- codd. Ath., -λεμ- Sch. Il.), Call. Fr. 503 ( -λεμ- codd.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Ar. Eq. 1172, with a play on Pylos, as the scene of Cleonʼs triumph.
at or before the gate, Ἑρμῆς Anon. ap. D.L. 8.31, Sch. Il. 2.842; Π. Ὀρθώσιος,= Janus Geminus, Gloss. (v. πυλεύς).
Πύλαι) at Pylae, Δημήτηρ ἡ Πυλαίη Call. Epigr. 40.
door-keeper, epith. of Athena, Lyc. 356.

definition: πυλάοχος [ ᾱ], ον, = πυλοῦχος, epith. of Dionysus, Plu. Isid. 2.364f.

children.definition: gate-fastener, he that keeps the gates of hell, epith. of the god who held this office, Ἀΐδαο πυλάρταο Il. 8.367, cf. 13.415, Od. 11.277 (expld. by Apion as ὁ ταῖς πύλαις προσηρτημένος).
ἀγοραί S. Tr. 639 (lyr.).

gate-keeper, Il. 21.530, 24.681, A.R. 3.747; of Odysseus in the Wooden Horse, Tryph. 201; [ κύνας] πυλαωρούς Il. 22.69 (quoted ap. Arr. Epict. 3.22.80, but θυραωρούς Aristarch.); π. Πλούτωνος Κέρβερος AP 7.319. ( πυλᾰ-sorwó- (cf. ἐρύω (B)) became πυλᾰ-(h)ορ(ϝ)ό-, πυλᾰορό-, πυλωρό-, then Ep. πυλᾰωρό- (with -ω- taken from the contr. form): πυλᾰ-(h)ορ(ϝ)ό- also became πυλαυρός, πυλευρός (qq. v.), and πυλαουρός ( v.l. in Il. 24.681), πυλαορός ( v.l. in 21.530).)
Janus Geminus, Gloss. (nisi leg. Πυλαῖος).
Democr. 288*, Opp. C. 3.419, AP 5.241 ( Eratosth.), 7.70 ( Jul.Aegypt.), Nonn. D. 3.136, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Lacon. for a wreath, Alcm. 16, Call. Fr. 358, Pamphil. ap. Ath. 15.678a.

one wing of a pair of double gates, ὀλίγον τι παρακλίναντες τὴν ἑτέρην π. Hdt. 3.156: mostly in pl., gates of a town (whereas θύρα = house-door), Σκαιαὶ π. Il. 3.145, etc.; π. εὖ ἀραρυίας 7.339; πύκα στιβαρῶς ἀραρυίας 12.454; πεπταμένας ἐν χερσὶ π. ἔχετε 21.531; ἄνεσάν τε π. καὶ ἀπῶσαν ὀχῆας ib. 537; π. ἀνοῖξαι A. Ag. 604; π. κλῇσαι Pl. R. 560c (the Art. is freq. omitted even in Prose): pl. of several gates, A. Th. 125; ἐν πύλαις in or at the gates, ib. 160, 213 (both lyr.), al.; πρὸς πύλαις ib. 377, 457; ἐπὶ ταῖς πύλαισιν, οὗ τὸ τάριχος ὤνιον Ar. Eq. 1247.

data.quote: ὀλίγον τι παρακλίναντες τὴν ἑτέρην π.
ἐπὶ ταῖς πύλαισιν, οὗ τὸ τάριχος ὤνιον

children.definition: house-door, δωμάτων πύλαι A. Ch. 732, cf. 561; γυναικείους π. gate or door leading to the womenʼs apartments, ib. 878; πύλαις διπλαῖς ἐνήλατο S. OT 1261; ἐκτὸς αὐλείων πυλῶν Id. Ant. 18: also in sg., ib. 1186, El. 818; of the door of a tent, Id. Aj. 11; πύλης ἄναξ θυρωρέ Id. Fr. 775.
πύλαι Ἀΐδαο the gates of the nether world, periphr.for hell, Il. 5.646, 9.312, Od. 14.156; Ἅιδου πύλαι A. Ag. 1291, cf. Ev.Matt. 16.18, etc.; also σκότου πύλαι E. Hec. 1; νερτέρων π. Id. Hipp. 1447.

custom-house, PTeb. 5.34 (ii B.C.); τετελώνηται διὰ πύλης has paid the customs, BGU 1592 (iii A.D.), etc.; τὸ σύμβολον τῆς ἱερᾶς Συηνιτικῆς π. PStrassb. 79.10 (i B.C.); μισθωταὶ ἱερᾶς π. Σοήνης Ostr. 106 (ii A.D.), al., cf. Ostr.Bodl. v C 1 (ii A.D.),

data.quote: τὸ σύμβολον τῆς ἱερᾶς Συηνιτικῆς π.

children.label: II
children.definition: entrance, orifice, ἀμφὶ πύλας ἰσθμοῖο Emp. 100.19; ἀναπεπταμένας ἔχω τῶν ὤτων τὰς π. Ath. 4.169a; πύλας τοῖς ὠσὶν ἐπίθεσθε Pl. Smp. 218b; ἡλίου πύλαι, Pythag. name for the eyes, D.L. 8.29; portal fissure of the liver, π. καὶ δοχαὶ χολῆς E. El. 828, cf. Hp. Epid. 2.4.1, Anat. 1, Pl. Ti. 71c, Arist. HA 496b32, Gal. 15.145; portal vein of the liver, Ruf. Onom. 179, Gal. 2.785,5.542.

data.quote: ἀναπεπταμένας ἔχω τῶν ὤτων τὰς π.

children.label: b
children.definition: carceres in the circus, Aristid. 1.124J.

children.label: c
children.definition: πύλας ὕμνων ἀναπιτνάμεν Pi. O. 6.27; ἐπέων π. B. Fr. 4; ἐν πύλαις γήρως D.C. 57.24, cf. 76.7.

entrance into a country through mountains, pass, Hdt. 5.52: hence, Πύλαι, αἱ, the common name for Θερμοπύλαι, the Gates of Greece, Id. 7.201, etc.: of other passes, π. τῆς Κιλικίας καὶ τῆς Συρίας X. An. 1.4.4; αἱ Σύριαι π. ib. 5; αἱ Κάσπιαι π. Str. 11.12.1; π. Λύδιαι Id. 13.1.65; Ἀμανίδες π. Id. 14.5.18, 16.2.8 ( αἱ Ἀμανικαὶ καλούμεναι Arr. An. 2.7.1): these passes were sometimes really barred by gates, Hdt. 7.176, cf. 3.117, 5.52, X. l.c.: the Isthmus is called πόντοιο πύλαι, Pi. N. 10.27; Κορίνθου π. Id. O. 9.86; αἱ π. τῆς Πελοποννήσου X. Ages. 2.17; Πέλοπος νάσου θεόδματοι π. B. p.437 J.

data.quote: π. τῆς Κιλικίας καὶ τῆς Συρίας

children.definition: narrow straits, by which one enters a broad sea, Πύλαι Γαδειρίδες the Straits of Gibraltar, Pi. Fr. 256; ἐπʼ αὐταῖς στενοπόροις λίμνης π., of the Thracian Bosporus, A. Pr. 729; ἐν πύλαις, of the Euripus, E. IA 803.

definition: Πυληγόροι: τελῶναι, καὶ οἱ τῶν πανηγύρεων ἐπιμεληταί, Hsch.; cf. Πυλαγόρος.

children.definition: watching at the door, of Hermes, h.Merc. 15.

definition: πυλιάς, άδος, ἡ, an unknown precious stone, f.l. (in gen. pl.) for πολυειδῶν, Aristeas 66.

children.definition: hair about the posteriors, Hsch. (pl.); also, curls, Id. (Cf. Skt. pulakas ‘bristling hairs’, Ir. ulcha ‘beard’.)

Dim. of πύλη, little gate, postern, Hdt. 1.180, 186, Th. 4.110, SIG 813 B 6 ( Delph., i A.D.), etc.; ὁ Ἑρμῆς ὁ πρὸς τῇ π. D. 47.26; π. χάρακος Onos. 10.20; τὸν . . τοῖχον σὺν τῇ π. CIG 1948 (inc. loc.).

children.label: II
children.definition: multiple fistula, Gal. 15.329.

definition: πυλλεῖ: θραύει, λέγει, διαβοᾷ, θρυλλεῖ, Hsch.

children.definition: from Pylos, Od. 16.323.
born in Pylos, Il. 2.54, 23.303; cf. Πυληγενής.
shutter, i.e. warden, of the gate, Documenti antichi dell’ Africa italiana 2.101 ( Cyrene, i A.D.).
to or towards Pylos, Il. 11.760, Od. 3.182.
πύλη, only ἐν πύλῳ Il. 5.397 Aristarch. ap. Sch.; better ἐν Πύλῳ Paus. 6.25.3.

Pylos, ἐν Π. ἠγαθέῃ Il. 1.252; Πύλου ἱερῆς Od. 21.108, cf. Pi. P. 5.70, Ar. Eq. 1058, Th. 4.39, etc.; but Π. ἠμαθόεντος Il. 2.77, al., Hes. Sc. 360; λέγεται καὶ θηλυκῶς καὶ ἀρσενικῶς St.Byz.: masc. in Str., 8.3.26 (sg. and pl.), al.

definition: πυλουρός, ὁ, = πυλωρός, Hdt. 3.72, 77, 118, 140, 156 (with v.l. πυλωρός in 72, 156), Baur and Rostovtzeff Second Report on Dura-Europos 138 (ii A.D.), Gloss.: as fem., ib.

children.definition: beam supporting gates, J. AJ 3.6.2 (pl.).
furnish with gates, τὸν Πειραιᾶ X. HG 5.4.34:— Pass., to be so furnished, ἅπαντʼ ἐκεῖνα πεπύλωται πύλαις Ar. Av. 1158.
gateway, in pl., A. Th. 408, 799, E. Hipp. 808, Ph. 1113, etc.

gateway, Arist. Mu. 398a16 (pl.), PCair.Zen. 193.9 (iii B.C.), PEnteux. 74.3 (iii B.C.), Sammelb. 6157 (ii B.C.), IG 3.398 (pl.); freq. separated from the house or temple to which it gave entrance, gate-tower, gate-house, IPE 12.32 B48 ( Olbia, iii B.C.), Plb. 4.18.2, Luc. Hipp. 5, etc.; of a temple, Plu. Tim. 12; τετράθυρος π. Callix. 1; π. τὸ μῆκος δίπλεθρος D.S. 1.47, cf. Luc. Nigr. 23; ἡ θύρα τοῦ π. Act.Ap. 12.13.
warder, gate-keeper, BGU 14v2 (iii A.D.).
keep the gate, Luc. DMort. 6[20].1, etc.; ὁ πινοτήρης π. τὴν κόγχην Plu. Sollert. 2.980b: metaph., γλῶσσα π. τὴν γεῦσιν Ps.-Democr. ap. Hp. Ep. 23, cf. PMag.Par. 2.158 (dub.).
of a warder, Aen.Tact. 28 tit.
porterʼs lodge, Poll. 1.77.

gate-keeper, warder, porter, A. Th. 621; π. πύργων, ναῶν, E. Tr. 956, IT 1227 (troch.); Ἅιδου κύων Id. HF 1277: as fem., ἡ π. δωμάτων γυνή Id. IT 1153: in Prose, Aen.Tact. 28.2, al., LXX Ne. 7.1, al., Ph. 2.216; of the guards of the Propylaea at Athens, IG 2(2).2297: metaph., τοῖον πυλωρὸν φύλακα . . τροφῆς such a watchful guardian of thy life, S. Aj. 562; κακοὺς π. ὑμᾶς, ὦ Κορίνθιοι, ἡ Πελοπόννησος ἔχει Prov. ap. Plu. Apophth. Lac. 2.221f.

children.label: II
children.definition: pylorus or lower orifice of the stomach, οἷον π. τις Gal. UP 4.7, cf. Nat.Fac. 3.4, Cels. 4.1.7, Ruf. Onom. 169, Id. ap. Orib. 7.26.34.
π., ἡ, os uteri, Ps.-Democr. ap. Hp. Ep. 23. (Cf. πυλαωρός.)

definition: πύματος [ ῠ], η, ον, Ep. Adj.

children.definition: hindmost, last, Il. 4.254; ἐν πυμάτοισι, opp. μετὰ πρώτοισι, 11.65; also, outmost, ἄντυξ ἣ π. θέεν ἀσπίδος 6.118, cf. 18.608; ῥινὸς ὕπερ π. above the root of the nose, 13.616; πυμάτῃ (sc. Ὕδρῃ) δʼ ἐπίκειται εἴδωλον κόρακος Arat. 448; nethermost, φάρος Pl. Epigr. 29.2 Diehl; π. Ταρτάρου βάθη Luc. Trag. 295; remotest, φωλειοί Opp. C. 3.451.

last, ἄνδρα κτείνας π. Il. 11.759; Οὖτιν ἐγὼ πύματον ἔδομαι Od. 9.369; ἀργειφόντῃ πυμάτῳ σπένδεσκον 7.138; π. τέλεον δρόμον . . ἵπποι Il. 23.373; π. δʼ ὁπλίσσατο δόρπον Od. 2.20; Trag. only in lyr., π. γῆρας S. OC 1236: neut. πύματον and πύματα as Adv., at the last, for the last time, πύματόν τε καὶ ὕστατον Il. 22.203; ὕστατα καὶ πύματα Od. 4.685, 20.13; ἐν πυμάτῳ S. OC 1675 (lyr.).
ὅ τι πύματον ὀλοίμαν by whatever is the last, worst fate, Id. OT 661 (lyr.).

bottom of a jar, cup, or other vessel, τὸν πύνδακα εἰσκρούειν knock in the bottom so as to make the cup hold less, a trick of wine-sellers, Pherecr. 105; μέτρῳ τὸν πύνδακα εἰσκεκρουμένῳ μετρεῖν prob. in Thphr. Char. 30.11 ( ἐκκεκρ- codd., and so ἐκκρουσαμένους τοὺς π. Ar. Fr. 270 codd. Poll.), cf. Arist. Pr. 938a13; bottom of a ship, Mim.Oxy. 413.103.

children.label: II
children.definition: sword-hilt, S. Fr. 311.

definition: πυνθάνομαι, Od. 2.315, etc.; poet. also πεύθομαι (q.v.): Ep. impf. πυνθανόμην 13.256: fut. πεύσομαι Il. 18.19, etc., Dor. πευσοῦμαι Theoc. 3.51 (so cod. Med. in A. Pr. 988): aor. ἐπῠθόμην Il. 5.702, etc., Ep. and Lyr. πυθόμην Od. 4.732, B. 15.26; imper. πυθοῦ, Ion. πυθεῦ Hdt. 3.68; Ep. opt. πεπύθοιτο Il. 6.50, al. ( subj. πεπύθωνται is f.l. for γε πύθωνται, 7.195); 3 pl. πυθοίατο S. OC 921: pf. πέπυσμαι Od. 11.505, etc.; 2 sg. πέπῠσαι Pl. Prt. 310b, Ep. πέπυσσαι Od. 11.494; inf. πεπύσθαι Th. 7.67, etc.; part. πεπυσμένος Pl. Smp. 179e: plpf. ἐπεπύσμην Ar. Pax 615, Av. 470; 3 sg. ἐπέπυστο Il. 13.674, Ep. πέπυστο ib. 521; 3 dual πεπύσθην 17.377:—

children.definition: learn, whether by hearsay or by inquiry ( ἐξιστορήσαντες τὰ ἐβούλοντο πυθέσθαι Hdt. 7.195): constr.

π. τί τινος learn something from a person, Il. 17.408, Od. 10.537, A. Ag. 599, Ar. Ra. 1417, etc.; also π. τι ἀπό τινος A. Ch. 737; ἐξ ἄλλων S. OC 1266; ἐκ τοῦ παρατυχόντος Th. 1.22; freq. παρά τινος, Hdt. 2.91, etc.; παρʼ ἄλλων (v.l. ἄλλων) X. Cyr. 4.1.3.
hear or learn a thing, Od. 2.411, A. Ch. 765, Antipho 5.25, etc.: abs., αἰσχρὸν τόδε γʼ ἐστὶ καὶ ἐσσομένοισι πυθέσθαι Il. 2.119, cf. Pi. P. 7.7, etc.; ὡς ἐγὼ πυνθάνομαι Hdt. 1.22, etc.

data.quote: αἰσχρὸν τόδε γʼ ἐστὶ καὶ ἐσσομένοισι πυθέσθαι

children.definition: hear or inquire concerning, πυθέσθαι πατρός, ἀγγελιάων, μάχης, Od. 1.281, 2.256, Il. 15.224, cf. S. El. 35, Pl. Lg. 635b.

π. τινά τινος inquire about one person of or from another, τὸν ἄνδρα τῶν ὁδοιπόρων Ar. Ach. 204; so π. περί τινος Hdt. 2.75; πᾶσαν πυθέσθαι τῶνδʼ ἀλήθειαν πέρι S. Tr. 91: c. acc. pers. only, inquire about a person, Ar. Th. 619.

part., πυθόμην ὁδὸν ὁρμαίνοντα that he was starting, Od. 4.732, cf. Hdt. 9.58, S. Aj. 692; π. τὸ Πλημμύριον ἑαλωκός Th. 7.31, cf. X. An. 1.7.16, etc.; οὔ πω . . πεπύσθην Πατρόκλοιο θανόντος they had not yet heard of his being dead, Il. 17.377, cf. 427, 19.322, A. Ch. 763; ὡς ἐπύθοντο τῆς Πύλου κατειλημμένης Th. 4.6: with acc. rei added, εἰ σφῶϊν τάδε πάντα πυθοίατο μαρναμένοιιν Il. 1.257.

data.quote: εἰ σφῶϊν τάδε πάντα πυθοίατο μαρναμένοιιν

children.definition: inf., hear or learn that . . , Hdt. 1.62, 5.15, S. Tr. 103 (lyr.), Th. 7.25, etc.

ὡς πυθώμεθα ὅπου ποτʼ ἐσμέν S. OC 11; αὐτοῦ π. τί ποτε νοεῖ inquire or learn from him what . ., Pl. La. 196c, cf. X. An. 6.3.25, Plb. 3.107.6; π., ὅτεῳ . . συνοικέει Hdt. 3.68; π. εἰ . . inquire whether . ., S. OC 993, IG 42(1).121.18 ( Epid., iv B.C.); τοῦ ξένου ἡδέως ἂν π., τί ταῦθʼ ἡγοῦντο Pl. Sph. 216d; π. τινῶν, ὅτι . . X. An. 4.6.17; π., ὅπως ἂν κάλλιστα πορευθείη ib. 3.1.7, cf. Cyr. 1.4.7.

data.quote: τοῦ ξένου ἡδέως ἂν π., τί ταῦθʼ ἡγοῦντο

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., aor. 1 part. fem. πεύσασα having learned, PMasp. 5.7 (vi A.D.).
boiled beans, Hsch. πυννιάζω, = πουνιάζω, Id.

with the fist, π. ἀγαθὸς Πολυδεύκης good with the fist, i.e. at boxing, Il. 3.237; πολὺ φέρτατος . . π. Od. 8.130; οὐ γὰρ π. γε μαχήσεαι Il. 23.621; π. μὲν ἐνίκησα Κλυτομήδεα ib. 634; περιγιγνόμεθʼ ἄλλων π. τε παλαισμοσύνῃ τε Od. 8.103; πειρηθήτω . . ἢ π. ἠὲ πάλῃ ib. 206; οἱ δὲ μάχοντο π. τε καὶ ἑλκηδόν Hes. Sc. 302; ἄνδρα π. ἀρετὰν εὑρόντα by boxing, Pi. O. 7.89; Ἴσθμιʼ ἑλὼν π. Simon. 158, cf. 154; πὺξ πεπληγέμεν Il. 23.660; πατάσσειν, παῖσαι, παίεσθαι, Ar. Ra. 547 (lyr.), X. An. 5.8.16, Lys. 4.6, etc.; π. ἐπὶ κόρρας ἤλασα Theoc. 14.34; τοὺς δακτύλους π. ἔχειν to have oneʼs fist clenched, Hp. Morb. 3.13. (Cf. Lat. pug-nus.)

data.quote: περιγιγνόμεθʼ ἄλλων π. τε παλαισμοσύνῃ τε
οἱ δὲ μάχοντο π. τε καὶ ἑλκηδόν

definition: πύξ, πῡγός, ἡ, later form for πυγή (q. v.). πύξαγρις, v. πτύξαγρις.

children.definition: thorn like the box-tree, = λύκιον, Dsc. 1.100: also πυξάκανθος, Lat. pyxacanthus, Plin. HN 12.31, 24.125, Gal. 12.63.
grove of box-trees, Gloss.
πυξίον 1, Ar. Fr. 846, Gloss.

children.label: II
children.definition: Dim. of πυξίς, PRyl. 125.14 (i A.D.), Sammelb. 4324.18, Sch. Ar. Eq. 902.
to be yellow like box-wood, Xenocr. ap. Orib. 2.58.63.

definition: πυξίνεος [ ῐ], α, ον, = πύξινος, AP 6.309 ( Leon.).

children.definition: with feet of box-wood, κλίνη Roussel Cultes Égyptiens 221 ( Delos, ii B.C.).

made of box-wood, ζυγόν Il. 24.269; πλαισίω (dual) IG 1(2).373.203; κλίνη Pl.Com. 34; πόδες κλίνης PGrenf. 1.14.7 ( ii B.C., cf. 2p.211); ἁλία Archipp. 13; φόρμιγξ Theoc. 24.110; κτένα AP 6.211 ( Leon.).
-ινον, τό, box-wood tablet, PGrenf. 1.14.12 ( ii B.C., pl.).

children.label: II
children.definition: yellow as box-wood, Χαιρεφῶν ὁ π. Eup. 239, cf. Philostr. VS 1 Praef., Sch. Ar. V. 1399, etc.; pyxinum [collyrium], Cels. 6.6.25.
tablet of box-wood for painting on, Anaxandr. 13, Amphis 51; for writing on, Ar. Fr. 845, Luc. Ind. 15.

children.label: II
children.definition: list, hence section, division, τῷ ὀγδόῳ π. τῆς γερουσίας Judeich Altertümer von Hierapolis No. 278.3, cf. 209.7 (prob.), 234.4 (pl.).

box of box-wood: generally, box (cf. A.D. Synt. 249.1), PRyl. 125.26 (i A.D.), Sammelb. 4324.17, Luc. Asin. 12, Philops. 21, etc.; π. χαλκῆ Trypho Trop. 1.2; π. ἰατρικαί Ph. Bel. 77.28, cf. Dsc. 3.11; for poison, J. BJ 1.30.7; so Lat. pyxis, Cic. Cael. 25.61, Juv. 13.25.

children.label: II
children.definition: cylinder in which a piston works, Hero Spir. 1.28.

children.label: IV
children.definition: plaster, Aët. 12.63, 15.15, Paul.Aeg. 3.78.
write or draw on a tablet, Artem. 1.51.
like box-wood, χρόα D.S. 3.35, cf. Dsc. 4.183.
box, Buxus sempervirens, Thphr. HP 3.15.5, Arist. Mu. 401a3, Mir. 831b23, etc. ( Hom. only has Adj. πύξινος): prov., πύξον εἰς Κύτωρον ἤγαγες ‘carry coals to Newcastle’, Eust. 88.3.
boxwood, IG 42(1).102.45 (Epid., iv. B.C.), Nic. Al. 579, Th. 516.
